Food was awesome (authentic - and you need to know what that means) and the sides were fresh and very well presented.

I could go for more of the sides (Wae Loo Oak - closed) did this amazing and this place could get 5 stars from me if they handled that a little better, but in all it was still awesome and amazing.

I think we freaked them out as the "suburban" kids who actually knew what we were doing, but once they saw that we could handle our own (tongs and scissors) then they played into the event and it was even better with (what we thought was the owner) critiquing our skills and then giving us an accepting smile.

They have the "higher end" SoJu but  I like that one as well.

Worth the trip and the stars.  Keep it up Koreana.

When I go out for Korean food I look forward to 2 things: 
1. Food served in a stone bowl that's hot enough to turn coal into diamonds 
2. At least a tinge of casual rudeness from the staff

Koreana delivered on both. 

I loved this place and personally my heart gives it a 5, but for the sake of full disclosure regarding it's quirky and imperfect (but still very much lovable) atmosphere, I'm going with a 4.

-- We walked in around 6:30 on a Sunday evening to dining room about 2/3 full --
Hostess: You have reservation? 
Me: No, we...
Hostess: **Walks away hurriedly**
Me to my partner: She just walked away... Does that mean 'go home'? What does that mean? I don't know what that means? 
Young Korean Family Who's Also Waiting To Be Sat: Yeah, they do that here. They'll seat you when they seat you and you won't get an estimated time.
Me: Good to know. 
-- About 15 minutes later the hostess woman comes over and tells us we'll sit "there" and points to a small table that's being cleaned in another dining room next to an oddly placed refrigerator in the middle of the dining area --
Me: Ok. 

They put menus on our table and walked away and it took us a few minutes to figure out that we needed to press the button on the table to call a server and order. We knew going in that there likely wouldn't be a ton of veggie options, so we usually end up with dolsat bibimbop, which is just fine by me. 

We also got their spicy tofu appetizer that wasn't spicy at all, but I'm a person who likes stuff super spicy to the point where your nose is running into mouth and I pretty much always find myself feeling like Korean spice levels are ultra tame. 

We kind of only ordered the tofu appetizer because my partner was worried the bibimbop wouldn't be enough to split (even thought it always is) and this was one of like 3 veggie options on the menu. We weren't expecting much, but what we got was an absolutely huge portion of perfect tofu, scallions, and a light spicy sauce that we came very close to fighting over. I will get this dish every time I come back... in fact, we might have to get two of these dishes to avoid any kind of sharing debacles. 

Next came the banchan, which they're more than happy to refill endlessly, and miso soup that apparently comes with any order of bibimbop. The miso was the least salty I've ever had and very good (even though I do crave the sodium). 

The bibimbop came as expected in a monstrous stone bowl with all the trimmings. They were diligent in ensuring that no meat made it's way into any of our dishes and we appreciated that as 80% of time that isn't the case. The egg wasn't as runny as we'd hoped, but did let the bowl sit extra long to crisp the rice so that could be on us. 

The servers won't come by unless you buzz them, and I kind of like that. Highly efficient. The atmosphere isn't the greatest and it isn't a spotless place, but what can you expect at a place that lets customers cook their own food? When we left the bar was absolutely stacked with glasses that needed to be dumped and washed and they don't appear to have central air by the looks of the 8 different portable AC units that definitely make the place a tad loud and even though the place is small, there's about 12 televisions throughout both dining rooms so no matter where you're sitting you can watch at least 3 of them... all set to golf... which everyone in there was watching intently. 

Final tip: Make a reservation... no matter the day/time/number in your party, you'll avoid what could be a lot of confusion and awkwardness with just a little phone call.

I LOVE the food here, yet the service is very bad, especially if you are an American woman alone. I have eaten there MANY times in the last 10 years, since I live only about 10 minutes away, yet I'm usually alone when I go there, and have to wait a while to give my order and receive the soup, etc. I LOVE eating at Korean restaurants, since they usually give you between 5-8 small dishes of kimchi, veggies, etc. with your meal. The prices have gotten expensive also, so I will not go back here, unless I'm with other people who like Korean food also. I like when many Korean families or groups come in and enjoy their meals and ambiance.

I am giving 2 stars in hopes for Koreana go back what they used to be. The service used to be much better even when they were full house. Tonight, the restaurant was not busy at all, but service was super slooow. Not sure what happened.

Excellent Korean food - very authentic and attentive staff!  Don't forget to try some infamous soju with your meal, and at least one of the great appetizers.  I had the dumplings which are far better than any dumpling I have had in an Asian restaurant!  It's entertaining just to watch the different dishes coming to the table, many of which are in boiling hot pots, or cook at your own table.  This is truly a great meal experience!

Korean food. Who doesn't love Korean food?

I heard a lot of good things about this place - the food and the the ambiance.

Koreana is placed within a strip mall, therefore is a huge parking lot and entrance is clearly visible. On the night that I went, there were several smokers outside the entrance doing their thing. Personally, I don't mind the smokers, but parents with children who are going to eat there are going to be a little annoyed. 

My friends and I walked into the foyer and the smells were AWESOME. The place was packed we waited for 10 minutes to get a table.

As hostess walked us to our table, I looked around at the decor. The place is medium-sized with a party room to the right side of the main dining room. I noticed that there's a bar and TVs in the room. I was expecting to see Korean television, but it was an American baseball game ... :( ... the food portions on the the tables of patrons were huge!

We looked at the menu as a family. I didn't look at the menu beforehand. I was quite angry to find out that if you want Korean BBQ, that there's a 2 order minimum. That's sad. They don't even have a website ... /sadder

I was really hungry for dol sot bibimbap - which I got. My friend got the pork bulgogi. For an appetizer - we got the pajeon. 

Here's the dish-by-dish breakdown:

- The dol sot bibimbap - Bean Sprouts. Gosari. Cucumber. Pickled Vegetables. Spinach. Fried Egg. Seaweed Flakes. I asked for a raw egg, which I'm used to eating vice a fried egg on top. The waitress and hostess didn't know what I was talking about ... /sad

- The pork belly bulgogi was a little underwhelming, however, IMHO, it was bo ssam served with lettuce leaves, white rice, typical sides of pickled vegetables, doenjang (fermented bean paste) ... honestly, my bo ssam/pork belly bulgogi is much better. 

- The pajeon - it was huge, and very filling. It was a little greasy and it needed more scallions. The dipping sauce needed a little work - it needed more acid (lemon juice).

Overall, it's a good experience. I will try the kalbi next time, but I personally can make better Korean food and I'm FILIPINO!

Great Korean food if you are looking for something in the Schaumburg area. The place will get pretty busy during dinner time. There's always a large group of Koreans coming off of shuttle buses that dine here.

On a Friday right after work (around 8pm), there wasn't much of a wait for a party of 2. Maybe we were just lucky. The restaurant was packed and a line developed later in the evening. I love that feeling when you're at an awesome place but didn't have to wait!

I got the yukgaejang which is a Korean beef soup. The ingredients tasted fresh and the soup was hearty and well seasoned. It's mildly spicy, but definitely nothing compared to other spicy Korean dishes. 

My friend ordered the dolsot (hot stone bowl) bibimbap. It looked fresh and yummy. 

The banchans (free side dishes) didn't disappoint, usually my favorite part of eating at a Korean restaurant. And as with other Korean restaurants, they'll keep the banchans coming to your heart's content. 

The food was a tiny bit on the pricier side, I  think, for this kind of cuisine, but at least it was quality. Overall, I was quite satisfied. This was one of the better Korean restaurants I'd been to in a while.
Service was very slow. Had the kimchi jigae and I was not a fan of it as the dish wasn't very flavorful. Husband loved his bibimbap though!

I have been coming here since I was 10 years old.  They changed owners over the years and this one is the best by far.  The food here is fresh and they serve good quality meat unlike other Korean restaurants.  The spicy soups are amazing here.   Love this place

Never again.....the service was careless and uninspired. 
The meal was served piecemeal; appetizer and one entree first. 45 minute wait for the second entree. 
The hot tea was apparently left over from lunch and stone cold.
The food is so-so and priced higher than it merits.
I won't be back.

Have been here for at least 10 times, near to my previous office.
Good for lunch and dinner for me.

If you want simple lung just order the Dumplings soup, which is healthy and good for lunch.
If you want to have a big meal, traditional Korean BBQ is so good for family gathering or friends parties. Beef tongue, Porkbelly, or just regular chicken, pork or beef bugulgi is wonderful enough to make your stomach satisfied.

Cold noodle is good but not my style. 

Dol all bb bam is always attractive for me, whether lunch or dinner.

Service is good if you show some respect to those kind and helpful folks.

What else? Say Hi to your Korean friends!

Food took forever,  it wasn't even busy,  they sat us near the door and every time the door opened I was greeted by the most chilling cold breeze ever, the server never came around when I needed her,   food was not worth the wait, I do not recommend it and they also seem racist to non Asian people,  because we waited,  some other Hispanic people were waiting forever,  but a few Asian tables got their food first despite coming in after us.

My friend and I ordered the Korean BBQ for 2 and I have never been so satisfied with a meal in my life! We took our time, tried every combination imaginable, and left a few pounds heavier than we arrived. SO worth it!

The staff was very helpful and accommodating, the dining area was clean and open, and the food was AMAZING!

If I lived nearby, I would eat here every day.
Overpriced and blended food.  Not worth the money.  Service is OK.  Nothing special. I don't know why people like this place.  Yelp failed.

This place was pretty f*cking good! Coming from LA where there's kbbq places in every corner, I didn't really have high expectations coming into this place. But this place definitely exceeded my expectations! Their kalbi was the best. Prices were very reasonable. Service was very nice and attentive. No complaints 
Will definitely come back when I'm in the area again
Awesome place! Very nice people in charge. Good Korean bbq. Noodles can be very spicy if you choose and my family and I love spicy so it was nice.
Koreana has real, authentic Korean; the prices are steep but worth it. If you like spice, and you are white, be sure to tell them because they seem to assume that white means no spice.

I've visited this location for almost 30 years; it's gone through a few owners, and there have been ups and downs because of it. But the current owner does things right. Even though I don't live anywhere near the place, I make a point of dropping in a lot. 

The food is just outstanding, plain and simple. No matter what I or my friends order, it's delicious. The bulgogi, bibim bap, and chap chae are my favorites. There's also a special place in my heart for their kimchee stew, especially on a day like today where the wind chill is below zero. Any time we had a question about a dish, the staff always gave a thorough answer. We've also asked for suggestions, and were happy with the recommendations.

Speaking of the staff...the servers are no-nonsense, efficient, and attentive, but not in the overly solicitous way Americans seem to expect. Which, frankly, is a relief. Your server won't come by every few minutes to ask if they can get you anything, or top off the water glass you've barely touched. If you want something, press the call button at your table, or simply raise your hand to get a server's attention, and they will respond quickly. Otherwise, they're going to give you space to enjoy your meal and your friends. To be honest, I wish more restaurants were like this.

You want "authentic" Korean - go here,  You want to cook at your table - go here, you want true small restaurant atmosphere - go here. Yout want amazing Korean BBQ and the sides that go with it - go here.

You want high-brow and to be waited on hand and foot - avoid here ,but this ain't (sic) that kind of place.

This place is amazing.  We are going back for sure.  Reservation made (and held - even though there were some "regulars" trying to "schmooze" their way in).  Great place.  They leave you alone, to the point where you have to flag them down in you actually want something - but we liked that.

Food was awesome (authentic - and you need to know what that means) and the sides were fresh and very well presented.

I could go for more of the sides (Wae Loo Oak - closed) did this amazing and this place could get 5 stars from me if they handled that a little better, but in all it was still awesome and amazing.

I think we freaked them out as the "suburban" kids who actually knew what we were doing, but once they saw that we could handle our own (tongs and scissors) then they played into the event and it was even better with (what we thought was the owner) critiquing our skills and then giving us an accepting smile.

They have the "higher end" SoJu but  I like that one as well.

Worth the trip and the stars.  Keep it up Koreana.

When I go out for Korean food I look forward to 2 things: 
1. Food served in a stone bowl that's hot enough to turn coal into diamonds 
2. At least a tinge of casual rudeness from the staff

Koreana delivered on both. 

I loved this place and personally my heart gives it a 5, but for the sake of full disclosure regarding it's quirky and imperfect (but still very much lovable) atmosphere, I'm going with a 4.

-- We walked in around 6:30 on a Sunday evening to dining room about 2/3 full --
Hostess: You have reservation? 
Me: No, we...
Hostess: **Walks away hurriedly**
Me to my partner: She just walked away... Does that mean 'go home'? What does that mean? I don't know what that means? 
Young Korean Family Who's Also Waiting To Be Sat: Yeah, they do that here. They'll seat you when they seat you and you won't get an estimated time.
Me: Good to know. 
-- About 15 minutes later the hostess woman comes over and tells us we'll sit "there" and points to a small table that's being cleaned in another dining room next to an oddly placed refrigerator in the middle of the dining area --
Me: Ok. 

They put menus on our table and walked away and it took us a few minutes to figure out that we needed to press the button on the table to call a server and order. We knew going in that there likely wouldn't be a ton of veggie options, so we usually end up with dolsat bibimbop, which is just fine by me. 

We also got their spicy tofu appetizer that wasn't spicy at all, but I'm a person who likes stuff super spicy to the point where your nose is running into mouth and I pretty much always find myself feeling like Korean spice levels are ultra tame. 

We kind of only ordered the tofu appetizer because my partner was worried the bibimbop wouldn't be enough to split (even thought it always is) and this was one of like 3 veggie options on the menu. We weren't expecting much, but what we got was an absolutely huge portion of perfect tofu, scallions, and a light spicy sauce that we came very close to fighting over. I will get this dish every time I come back... in fact, we might have to get two of these dishes to avoid any kind of sharing debacles. 

Next came the banchan, which they're more than happy to refill endlessly, and miso soup that apparently comes with any order of bibimbop. The miso was the least salty I've ever had and very good (even though I do crave the sodium). 

The bibimbop came as expected in a monstrous stone bowl with all the trimmings. They were diligent in ensuring that no meat made it's way into any of our dishes and we appreciated that as 80% of time that isn't the case. The egg wasn't as runny as we'd hoped, but did let the bowl sit extra long to crisp the rice so that could be on us. 

The servers won't come by unless you buzz them, and I kind of like that. Highly efficient. The atmosphere isn't the greatest and it isn't a spotless place, but what can you expect at a place that lets customers cook their own food? When we left the bar was absolutely stacked with glasses that needed to be dumped and washed and they don't appear to have central air by the looks of the 8 different portable AC units that definitely make the place a tad loud and even though the place is small, there's about 12 televisions throughout both dining rooms so no matter where you're sitting you can watch at least 3 of them... all set to golf... which everyone in there was watching intently. 

Final tip: Make a reservation... no matter the day/time/number in your party, you'll avoid what could be a lot of confusion and awkwardness with just a little phone call.

I LOVE the food here, yet the service is very bad, especially if you are an American woman alone. I have eaten there MANY times in the last 10 years, since I live only about 10 minutes away, yet I'm usually alone when I go there, and have to wait a while to give my order and receive the soup, etc. I LOVE eating at Korean restaurants, since they usually give you between 5-8 small dishes of kimchi, veggies, etc. with your meal. The prices have gotten expensive also, so I will not go back here, unless I'm with other people who like Korean food also. I like when many Korean families or groups come in and enjoy their meals and ambiance.

I am giving 2 stars in hopes for Koreana go back what they used to be. The service used to be much better even when they were full house. Tonight, the restaurant was not busy at all, but service was super slooow. Not sure what happened.

Excellent Korean food - very authentic and attentive staff!  Don't forget to try some infamous soju with your meal, and at least one of the great appetizers.  I had the dumplings which are far better than any dumpling I have had in an Asian restaurant!  It's entertaining just to watch the different dishes coming to the table, many of which are in boiling hot pots, or cook at your own table.  This is truly a great meal experience!

Korean food. Who doesn't love Korean food?

I heard a lot of good things about this place - the food and the the ambiance.

Koreana is placed within a strip mall, therefore is a huge parking lot and entrance is clearly visible. On the night that I went, there were several smokers outside the entrance doing their thing. Personally, I don't mind the smokers, but parents with children who are going to eat there are going to be a little annoyed. 

My friends and I walked into the foyer and the smells were AWESOME. The place was packed we waited for 10 minutes to get a table.

As hostess walked us to our table, I looked around at the decor. The place is medium-sized with a party room to the right side of the main dining room. I noticed that there's a bar and TVs in the room. I was expecting to see Korean television, but it was an American baseball game ... :( ... the food portions on the the tables of patrons were huge!

We looked at the menu as a family. I didn't look at the menu beforehand. I was quite angry to find out that if you want Korean BBQ, that there's a 2 order minimum. That's sad. They don't even have a website ... /sadder

I was really hungry for dol sot bibimbap - which I got. My friend got the pork bulgogi. For an appetizer - we got the pajeon. 

Here's the dish-by-dish breakdown:

- The dol sot bibimbap - Bean Sprouts. Gosari. Cucumber. Pickled Vegetables. Spinach. Fried Egg. Seaweed Flakes. I asked for a raw egg, which I'm used to eating vice a fried egg on top. The waitress and hostess didn't know what I was talking about ... /sad

- The pork belly bulgogi was a little underwhelming, however, IMHO, it was bo ssam served with lettuce leaves, white rice, typical sides of pickled vegetables, doenjang (fermented bean paste) ... honestly, my bo ssam/pork belly bulgogi is much better. 

- The pajeon - it was huge, and very filling. It was a little greasy and it needed more scallions. The dipping sauce needed a little work - it needed more acid (lemon juice).

Overall, it's a good experience. I will try the kalbi next time, but I personally can make better Korean food and I'm FILIPINO!

My husband and I were invited out to dinner by a Korean couple we know. This is the place for authentic Korean barbeque. I can't tell you what exactly it was that we had, but it was great. Our hosts cooked our food for us, according to tradition, at the table. A platter of thinly sliced meats was brought out, in addition to head on shrimp. We also had soup that was loaded with vegetables, meat, and noodles. The soup was also cooked at the table and whenever the liquid level went down the owner added more broth. There were sauces and traditional sides. Hope to go back again.

Nothing special. I had nangmyun and it was ok. Side dishes were variety but taste was ok. It was very crowded at 8:40 pm on tuesday. 
I would not come here again unless I am really hungry for korean food.

I have definitely experienced better. I guess the caliber of Korean cuisine was just not what I expected or what I am used to (given that I am a Northern California girl who grew up with an abundance of Korean restaurants in the vicinity of my hometown). 

Anyway, all biases aside, Koreana makes a good effort - and I figure that the style of Korean cuisine in the Midwest is just unlike that of either coast - so I really cannot hold Koreana responsible for that. The restaurant owners are Korean, and the majority of the restaurant patrons are Asian, which is always a good sign when trying out a new ethnic restaurant. The restaurant is relatively spacious, and for a place that does a lot of kBBQ, it does not leave a strong stench on your clothing, which is great. 
 
We chose to stick with our usual menu items: my mom ordered the stone bowl bibimbap and I ordered a seafood tofu soup. The bibimbap was average, and in all honesty, you really can't get bibimbap wrong. All you really need is the bibimbap paste/sauce to make any regular ol' bowl of white rice taste like a bibimbap. The ingredients seemed plentiful enough, but once again, it didn't make a very big impression. 

My seafood tofu soup was all but too spicy for me. It wasn't until the piping hot bowl came to the table that I realized that the waitress had never asked me how spicy I wanted the tofu soup....well, I spent the next 10 minutes fishing out the layer of hot oil from the surface of my soup. Also, the 'seafood' was a few measly pieces of calamari and oysters - really not enough to merit the extra cost. 

The banchan wasn't great either. The assortment was lacking, and honestly, all of the side dishes were kind of sad and limp looking. Usually, we go through a few refills of banchan over the duration of our meal, but here, we didn't even touch half of the side dishes. I noticed that many other neighboring tables also left their banchan untouched, which speaks volumes about the preparation of the side dishes.

I think Koreana suffices if you are in the area and really craving some sort - any sort - of Korean food. Perhaps Koreana is better for kBBQ than it is for their other menu items - so that could be our fault as well. Needless to say, I probably won't be back for their bibimbap or tofu soup.

Love this place! The little Korean lady is so nice and always on point with customer service. I always get the pork bulgogi-- and although I should try some of their other hits, it's this specific dish that I crave for every single time I come here. I usually come during lunch so the fresh bulgogi is served on a sizzling plate with a variety of endless DELICIOUS banchan (sides).
Yummy meat and korean veggie sides of all kinds.
I love this place.    Come here every year from las vegas when I travel for business.   Service and owners are awesome.  Kalbi is the bomb

Texture and flavor - these are the reasons why Koreana stands out among other local Korean restaurants. Except for TTOWA, I can't think of another Korean restaurant I've been to in the area which has executed both perfectly.

Don't miss the seafood pancake here. Full of seafood and egg flavor, this entree sized appetizer is what seafood hash browns would taste like. Tons of chopped seafood, slightly crispy but slightly wet at the same time -- a perfect combination.

The kalbi tang has a strong flavor of short rib with clear noodles and tons of green onion. It's a perfect soup to drink on a cold day but not so overwhelming you couldn't drink it on any day.

The spicy tofu here stands out because the tofu has a silky smooth melt-in-your-mouth texture. I'm not vegetarian, but I couldn't stop myself from eating this.

One of my biggest gripes about stone bowl rice dishes is when the rice isn't crispy from the stone bowl. No problem here as the bibimbap was served extremely hot where you could hear the rice sizzle long after it is set on the table.

My favorite item was the rice cake with dumplings. Chewy rice cake with soft dumplings is probably one of my favorite chewy items next to mochi. The broth was perfectly light and but flavorful.

Without trying any of the Korean BBQ items, I'm already excited about this restaurant. I can't wait to go back and see what else I'm missing!

Food was okay, nothing special. It might have been a factor of us coming in 20 minutes before closing though, so keep that in mind if you plan to come here.

The service was pretty good, they didn't rush us even though closing time was fast approaching, which is good for a restaurant with a largely non-English menu. The food came out fairly quickly too.

I ordered fried rice. It was okay, like I said before, but that might be because the place was about to close. I feel like this place will need another try for proper Korean BBQ before I can accurately judge the quality of the food.
It all tastes good. Grilling at the table is fun.
This place is da bomb! Always crowded and there is a long wait around peak hours...but it is well worth the wait! Great food, great service!

Food was OK! Had our food cooked in their kitchen. Enjoyed the sides and meat was well seasoned. Nothing exciting compared to other Korean restaurants around. But what really got me is the poor service. No one came to our table to ask for our drinks. My husband had to literally stand up and approach the server to ask for water and still didn't get until we were asking for to go boxes for our leftover food. Not coming back.

The food was excellent but the service was horrible.  I felt scared to ask the server for anything.  The services seemed to be more concerned about a different large table that arrived after we did.  The service was slow, we had eaten there before and never was it so slow.  We didn't get hot tea upon arriving like other tables. We ordered 2 orders of bulgogi and 1 order of kalbi the waitress humored us asking if we could eat so much food.  WE LITERALLY HAD TO ASK FOR EVERYTHING!!!! It got to a point where i felt bad for asking, they were never concerned about anything we may need like refills on tea, water, or leaf lettuce.  We had to ask them to bring out and rice and soup.  Excellent food horrible service im sad to say.

Great place for Korean BBQ.  I'm not even sure what all we had.  We ordered so many different things and they kept bringing us more dishes to try.  You definitely do not leave here hungry.  Lots of Korean people dining here so that is probably a good sign.  The only issue I had with the whole meal was the fact that the server runs the BBQ grill at the table.  Our server kept cross-contaminating raw meat with cooked meat and that is a huge NO-NO!  She would touch raw meat with the tongs and then pull cooked meat off the BBQ and plate it up.  We finally had to show her the error of her ways and asked her not to do that.  She didn't quite get it so we finally took over the grilling operation.  The owner of the restaurant came by and chatted with us for a few minutes and then brought us some Korean wine on the house.  

A great time was had by all. 

Fast forward 6 hours....I was laying in bed, on the verge of good REM sleep when suddenly all hell broke loose. I had a gastrointestinal event like nothing I've ever imagined. Cramps, sweating, bloating beyond my worst nightmare. I've had food poisoning from some bad shellfish and that was almost like a skip in the park compared to what was going on inside me.

Then came the, uh, flatulence. Heavens to Murgatroyd, the sounds, like trumpets calling the demons back to Hell...the stench, like 1,000 rotten corpses vomited. I couldn't stand to stay in one room for fear of succumbing to my own odors.

But wait; there's more. 

What came out of me felt like someone tried to funnel Niagara Falls through a coffee straw. I swear my sphincter was screaming. It felt like my delicate starfish was a gaping maw projectile vomiting a torrential flood of toxic waste. 100% liquid. Flammable liquid. NAPALM. It was actually a bit humorous (for a nanosecond) as it was just beyond anything I could imagine possible.

AND IT WENT ON FOR HOURS.

I felt violated when it was over, which I think might have been sometime in the early morning of the next day. 

Will I go back?  Sure.  But next time, I'm running the grill.

I've been here twice. Once I sat in their regular dining room and ordered a meal cooked by their kitchen, and more recently I sat at the grill tables. I had a party of 8 and the staff was very attentive to our needs. 

The food is so yummy. The side dishes are authentic, fresh and tasty just like the rest of the food. 

I think this place has changed ownership and so some of the older reviews may not be accurate.

The owner and her husband were there, they are very friendly! When he found out that it was my birthday he brought out an apple with a b'day candle in it. So cute and thoughtful!

I've been to this place three times and each time loved it. I lived in Korea and I swear it's authentic. Good side dishes, huge portions to share. My favs are the mandu dumplings, chap chae and yuk kae jung. BBQ and hot pots are pricey for two people...

Curious about trying Korean cuisine but have been intimidated because of the language barrier? Tired of passing restaurants written in Hangul and have no idea what they mean? At Koreana, the servers speak English and the menus are translated with descriptions for added convenience. 

Koreana does a great job of welcoming non-Koreans. During the most recent visit, all of the diners were from diverse backgrounds and weren't Korean.
 
The menu has your popular items from soups to Korean BBQ and the prices were reasonable. I was taken back from the portion that came out for the spicy braised beef soup. The bowl itself was the size of my bathroom sink. 

In comparison to the other Korean restaurants in the area, I would definitely come based on for the food, portions, interior, prices, and service.

I've been to alot of korean places around the NW burbs, but this one had the best of everything. We didn't do the BBQ at the table. We all had entrees we shared family style & fried dumplings. I am thinking this deserves 5 stars. We will def be back.

I came here with my family to have some korean BBQ. Not really great for big parties that all want BBQ (only the smaller tables have the BBQ grill built-in) but since half of us wanted regular food, it was fine.

The meat was good but nothing spectacular. I was also disappointed with the panchans. We got about 7-9 (which sounds like a lot but I don't really think so). I so wish that sliced pickled daikon was more common here like it is in LA because I love to eat that with my bbq!

The seafood pajun was delicious. Perfect ratio of all the elements! The dukbokki was awesome too. I can't handle spicy well but this one had a very subtle spicy with a hit of tangy/sweet. These really bumped up my score just because I love a good pajun and this is my favorite dukbokki so far.

FYI it gets SMOKEY when this place fills up. I swear those vents aren't doing anything.

I met my boyfriend here for lunch and as far as Korean food goes, I was not impressed.  I think there are much better restaurants around.  One thing I have noticed is that Korean restaurants can either make an awesome Bulgogi or Jue Kah Jeng soup.  I have yet to find a restaurant that does a great job with both.  This was the case with Koreana.  The Bulgogi was great and a huge portion.  But my spicy soup was lacking in spice and ingredients.  It seemed watered down.  I had to add salt to give it some flavor.  I didn't even want to take the leftovers home... which says a lot if you know me at all!

The interior is a bit divey and dark.  The service was lacking.

Good and very close to authentic Korean foods. One star less because it is almost impossible to get a sitting for a lone-diner, especially during weekends.  Most tables are for group of 4 or more, which make it quite intimidating for when to ask a sitting for one person. Having the fact there are only very limited good Korean restaurants in the area, this kind of restaurant would be very popular with locals, which make it harder for an out-of-towner to drop by and expect to not get rushed out.

Nothing special. I had nangmyun and it was ok. Side dishes were variety but taste was ok. It was very crowded at 8:40 pm on tuesday. 
I would not come here again unless I am really hungry for korean food.

I have definitely experienced better. I guess the caliber of Korean cuisine was just not what I expected or what I am used to (given that I am a Northern California girl who grew up with an abundance of Korean restaurants in the vicinity of my hometown). 

Anyway, all biases aside, Koreana makes a good effort - and I figure that the style of Korean cuisine in the Midwest is just unlike that of either coast - so I really cannot hold Koreana responsible for that. The restaurant owners are Korean, and the majority of the restaurant patrons are Asian, which is always a good sign when trying out a new ethnic restaurant. The restaurant is relatively spacious, and for a place that does a lot of kBBQ, it does not leave a strong stench on your clothing, which is great.

The ingredients seemed plentiful enough, but once again, it didn't make a very big impression. 

My seafood tofu soup was all but too spicy for me. It wasn't until the piping hot bowl came to the table that I realized that the waitress had never asked me how spicy I wanted the tofu soup....well, I spent the next 10 minutes fishing out the layer of hot oil from the surface of my soup. Also, the 'seafood' was a few measly pieces of calamari and oysters - really not enough to merit the extra cost. 

The banchan wasn't great either. The assortment was lacking, and honestly, all of the side dishes were kind of sad and limp looking. Usually, we go through a few refills of banchan over the duration of our meal, but here, we didn't even touch half of the side dishes. I noticed that many other neighboring tables also left their banchan untouched, which speaks volumes about the preparation of the side dishes.

I think Koreana suffices if you are in the area and really craving some sort - any sort - of Korean food. Perhaps Koreana is better for kBBQ than it is for their other menu items - so that could be our fault as well. Needless to say, I probably won't be back for their bibimbap or tofu soup.

Love this place! The little Korean lady is so nice and always on point with customer service. I always get the pork bulgogi-- and although I should try some of their other hits, it's this specific dish that I crave for every single time I come here. I usually come during lunch so the fresh bulgogi is served on a sizzling plate with a variety of endless DELICIOUS banchan (sides).
Yummy meat and korean veggie sides of all kinds.
I love this place.    Come here every year from las vegas when I travel for business.   Service and owners are awesome.  Kalbi is the bomb

Texture and flavor - these are the reasons why Koreana stands out among other local Korean restaurants. Except for TTOWA, I can't think of another Korean restaurant I've been to in the area which has executed both perfectly.

Don't miss the seafood pancake here. Full of seafood and egg flavor, this entree sized appetizer is what seafood hash browns would taste like. Tons of chopped seafood, slightly crispy but slightly wet at the same time -- a perfect combination.

The kalbi tang has a strong flavor of short rib with clear noodles and tons of green onion. It's a perfect soup to drink on a cold day but not so overwhelming you couldn't drink it on any day.

The spicy tofu here stands out because the tofu has a silky smooth melt-in-your-mouth texture. I'm not vegetarian, but I couldn't stop myself from eating this.

One of my biggest gripes about stone bowl rice dishes is when the rice isn't crispy from the stone bowl. No problem here as the bibimbap was served extremely hot where you could hear the rice sizzle long after it is set on the table.

My favorite item was the rice cake with dumplings. Chewy rice cake with soft dumplings is probably one of my favorite chewy items next to mochi. The broth was perfectly light and but flavorful.

Without trying any of the Korean BBQ items, I'm already excited about this restaurant. I can't wait to go back and see what else I'm missing!

Food was okay, nothing special. It might have been a factor of us coming in 20 minutes before closing though, so keep that in mind if you plan to come here.

The service was pretty good, they didn't rush us even though closing time was fast approaching, which is good for a restaurant with a largely non-English menu. The food came out fairly quickly too.

I ordered fried rice. It was okay, like I said before, but that might be because the place was about to close. I feel like this place will need another try for proper Korean BBQ before I can accurately judge the quality of the food.
It all tastes good. Grilling at the table is fun.
This place is da bomb! Always crowded and there is a long wait around peak hours...but it is well worth the wait! Great food, great service!

Food was OK! Had our food cooked in their kitchen. Enjoyed the sides and meat was well seasoned. Nothing exciting compared to other Korean restaurants around. But what really got me is the poor service. No one came to our table to ask for our drinks. My husband had to literally stand up and approach the server to ask for water and still didn't get until we were asking for to go boxes for our leftover food. Not coming back.

The food was excellent but the service was horrible.  I felt scared to ask the server for anything.  The services seemed to be more concerned about a different large table that arrived after we did.  The service was slow, we had eaten there before and never was it so slow.  We didn't get hot tea upon arriving like other tables. We ordered 2 orders of bulgogi and 1 order of kalbi the waitress humored us asking if we could eat so much food.  WE LITERALLY HAD TO ASK FOR EVERYTHING!!!! It got to a point where i felt bad for asking, they were never concerned about anything we may need like refills on tea, water, or leaf lettuce.  We had to ask them to bring out and rice and soup.  Excellent food horrible service im sad to say.

Great place for Korean BBQ.  I'm not even sure what all we had.  We ordered so many different things and they kept bringing us more dishes to try.  You definitely do not leave here hungry.  Lots of Korean people dining here so that is probably a good sign.  The only issue I had with the whole meal was the fact that the server runs the BBQ grill at the table.  Our server kept cross-contaminating raw meat with cooked meat and that is a huge NO-NO!  She would touch raw meat with the tongs and then pull cooked meat off the BBQ and plate it up.  We finally had to show her the error of her ways and asked her not to do that.  She didn't quite get it so we finally took over the grilling operation.  The owner of the restaurant came by and chatted with us for a few minutes and then brought us some Korean wine on the house.  

A great time was had by all. 

Fast forward 6 hours....I was laying in bed, on the verge of good REM sleep when suddenly all hell broke loose. I had a gastrointestinal event like nothing I've ever imagined. Cramps, sweating, bloating beyond my worst nightmare. I've had food poisoning from some bad shellfish and that was almost like a skip in the park compared to what was going on inside me.

Then came the, uh, flatulence. Heavens to Murgatroyd, the sounds, like trumpets calling the demons back to Hell...the stench, like 1,000 rotten corpses vomited. I couldn't stand to stay in one room for fear of succumbing to my own odors.

But wait; there's more. 

What came out of me felt like someone tried to funnel Niagara Falls through a coffee straw. I swear my sphincter was screaming. It felt like my delicate starfish was a gaping maw projectile vomiting a torrential flood of toxic waste. 100% liquid. Flammable liquid. NAPALM. It was actually a bit humorous (for a nanosecond) as it was just beyond anything I could imagine possible.

AND IT WENT ON FOR HOURS.

I felt violated when it was over, which I think might have been sometime in the early morning of the next day. 

Will I go back?  Sure.  But next time, I'm running the grill.

I've been here twice. Once I sat in their regular dining room and ordered a meal cooked by their kitchen, and more recently I sat at the grill tables. I had a party of 8 and the staff was very attentive to our needs. 

The food is so yummy. The side dishes are authentic, fresh and tasty just like the rest of the food. 

I think this place has changed ownership and so some of the older reviews may not be accurate.

The owner and her husband were there, they are very friendly! When he found out that it was my birthday he brought out an apple with a b'day candle in it. So cute and thoughtful!

I've been to this place three times and each time loved it. I lived in Korea and I swear it's authentic. Good side dishes, huge portions to share. My favs are the mandu dumplings, chap chae and yuk kae jung. BBQ and hot pots are pricey for two people...

Curious about trying Korean cuisine but have been intimidated because of the language barrier? Tired of passing restaurants written in Hangul and have no idea what they mean? At Koreana, the servers speak English and the menus are translated with descriptions for added convenience. 

Koreana does a great job of welcoming non-Koreans. During the most recent visit, all of the diners were from diverse backgrounds and weren't Korean.
 
The menu has your popular items from soups to Korean BBQ and the prices were reasonable. I was taken back from the portion that came out for the spicy braised beef soup. The bowl itself was the size of my bathroom sink. 

In comparison to the other Korean restaurants in the area, I would definitely come based on for the food, portions, interior, prices, and service.

I've been to alot of korean places around the NW burbs, but this one had the best of everything. We didn't do the BBQ at the table. We all had entrees we shared family style & fried dumplings. I am thinking this deserves 5 stars. We will def be back.

I came here with my family to have some korean BBQ. Not really great for big parties that all want BBQ (only the smaller tables have the BBQ grill built-in) but since half of us wanted regular food, it was fine.

The meat was good but nothing spectacular. I was also disappointed with the panchans. We got about 7-9 (which sounds like a lot but I don't really think so). I so wish that sliced pickled daikon was more common here like it is in LA because I love to eat that with my bbq!

The seafood pajun was delicious. Perfect ratio of all the elements! The dukbokki was awesome too. I can't handle spicy well but this one had a very subtle spicy with a hit of tangy/sweet. These really bumped up my score just because I love a good pajun and this is my favorite dukbokki so far.

FYI it gets SMOKEY when this place fills up. I swear those vents aren't doing anything.

I met my boyfriend here for lunch and as far as Korean food goes, I was not impressed.  I think there are much better restaurants around.  One thing I have noticed is that Korean restaurants can either make an awesome Bulgogi or Jue Kah Jeng soup.  I have yet to find a restaurant that does a great job with both.  This was the case with Koreana.  The Bulgogi was great and a huge portion.  But my spicy soup was lacking in spice and ingredients.  It seemed watered down.  I had to add salt to give it some flavor.  I didn't even want to take the leftovers home... which says a lot if you know me at all!

The interior is a bit divey and dark.  The service was lacking.

Good and very close to authentic Korean foods. One star less because it is almost impossible to get a sitting for a lone-diner, especially during weekends.  Most tables are for group of 4 or more, which make it quite intimidating for when to ask a sitting for one person. Having the fact there are only very limited good Korean restaurants in the area, this kind of restaurant would be very popular with locals, which make it harder for an out-of-towner to drop by and expect to not get rushed out.

$7.99 lunch special. OMG. If you're familiar with Korean food, you probably expect to get a nice lunch, some rice, a bowl of soup, and some banchan (side dishes). That's what you get here.

Only...you also get refills on the banchan. And the rice. And your hot tea (if you drink hot tea). No extra charge. The portions on the main lunch items are also extremely generous.

I'm talking, you won't want dinner if you eat lunch here, because you'll be too full. Added to that, the food is seriously great. I haven't tried everything here yet, but don't worry -- I'll work on it.

Someday, we'll have to go for Korean BBQ, too. :9

so good. get here early or you won't get to cook your own.  there were five of us and we ordered two plan steaks to cook your own. and a couple of cold noodle soups to share (nangmeum).  they give you plenty of leaf lettuce to make wraps, use both sauces they give you. so good.  This is a meat dish, there is no rice.  when you are done, they use the hot pot to make kimchee fried rice!  they tossed in all the leftover ban chan and made some flavorful rice, and gave you a bowl of soup to eat it with.  so much food.  everything was fresh and good.
This place is amazing!! I've not tried the BBQ, but the Tofu, Pork, Kimchee dish on the sizzling platter is amazing, add the chap chae, and a beer and you are going to have a good night!

My group made reservations and boy am I glad we did. We went there on a Saturday night at 7 for dinner and it was packed. The signature meal here is grilling at your table. They'll bring you plates full of sliced meats and you cook them yourself. We got a combo platter, which had a good assortment of different things, including two large, whole shrimp. Its not very filling, but it is delicious! Their traditional Korean dishes are also great, so if you're looking for Korean but not necessarily bbq, then this place is still a must-go.

Great layout, great atmosphere and friendly service. Food comes out fresh and smoking hot (literally!) Nice little find. The staff is friendly and always on top of their game. They are quick and even quicker if you need them, push the little button on the wall by your table, it's magic powers will summon someone post haste to help you with whatever your needs be. 

The owner is a humble man who has no problem walking around greeting and chatting to everyone. Lovely place. It's good to step outside the regular places and venture into a new world like this. Like you fantastically stepped out and into a new country without the hassle of airplane tickets and the terrible tsa.

I ventured here on a Wednesday and it was packed and full of energy. Loved it.

I'd give this local korean joint a 3.5 stars. Not a 4 star cuz their Galbitang was a total disappointment & they ran out of hot barley tea! But i still love korean food :D


:: VENUE ::
The inside was clean & the place felt homey with an Asian decor. We got in around 8:30pm on a Tuesday night. The place was just a forth full until 9pm hits then all of a sudden it got jammed packed! Since I'm not from the area I had not expected to see a restaurant all full of koreans - mostly ahjummas & ahjussis.  


:: NON-BBQ FOODS ::
(1) Galbitang 
     - broth was very bland & not rich tasting - as if not simmered long enough with seasoned ribs or daikon 
     - way too much noodles  & barely any broth 
     - the chopped up scallions could have been a cooked a little longer

(2) BiBim Neng Myun
    - best part of the whole meal
    - noodles were very chewy
    - tangy iced broth (I added more vinegar for more tanginess)
    - just enough spicy gochujang dressing to give it a kick

(3) Banchans
    - kimchi was too sour tasting
    - spinich, potato & the fish cake were my favorites

    
:: COSTS ::
Their prices were a bit higher than I would have expected to pay. But lucky us this one was on the company's expense~
The staff were really friendly and came by to check on us regularly. Huge difference since my last visit. The food came out fast and it was good
Amazing food and extremely friendly and super fast service. It was an amazing first time there!! Loved everything we had today! I would definitely come back to this place when I'm in town again!

Great authentic Korean food! The husband and I went here for a late lunch while we were up north. I have had Korean food from time to time but never have I ate at an actual Korean restaurant. Goodness I am so glad we came here. 

Appetizer: Fried Dumplings: crispy outside and gooey deliciousness inside. These were the best dumplings we ever had. I could eat them everyday. I barely use the sauce because they were so good on their own. I truly suggest trying these babies.

Main Course: Since we were grilling our own food (more details further below), we had to purchase two proteins - beef brisket and thick pork belly. The pork belly came out first. The ladies set up the grill and put it on for us. It was our first time doing this so the wonderful ladies did not mind essentially cooking the meat for us. I felt kinda bad but I am glad they were so helpful. One of the ladies show us how to make the lettuce wrap and the best sides to put in it. Oh boy. So flavorful. So tender. So heavenly. The hubby who doesn't even eat pork devour half the dish. :) On to the brisket, as a beef loving girl I couldn't get enough. It was thinly sliced and cooked quickly. It did take a little more to enhance the flavor but it was lovely. I have to say I preferred the pork belly. o

Sides: With every meal, Koreans have several side dishes, kimchi being a primary.  We had two different kinds including Napa cabbage kimchi, a staple. It wasn't the best kimchi I ever had but it was still enjoyable. We also had cole slaw, bean sprouts, a potato like item that was sweet. Something that resembled pickles but was not tarty just mushy. And finally a beefy thing. Have no idea what it was but it was good. 

Bonus: With the order of brisket, you will get Korean Miso soup. How can I explain this spicy, hot bowl of dreams. I love Japanese Miso. I truly do, but this topped all miso for me. I am not jaded and nothing would match this. It was extremely temperature hot so don't dig right in like I did. Wait but don't forget it.

Overall: The experience was phenomenal and the food even better. The aunties there were cold but friendly and it seems the local Koreans like to visit this place often. I couldn't continue to describe how good this place was. Just listen: I will be dreaming of this food for a very long time. Now I have to plan another trip up to Schaumburg.

We just watched an episode of Anthony Bourdain and my fiance wanted to try some KBBQ. Ive read many reviews on yelp for this place and shop in the strip mall often.
Stopped in for lunch on a snowy January day. The place was pretty full. It was the boys first time having korean bbq and only my second.

We ordered the combo with: kalbi, beef bulogi, chicken bulogi, shrimp, veggies, and pork for ~$40. Being newbies at this, Im sure our waitress thought we needed some help.

First, the sides. My favorite was this shredded beef, it was sweet and spicy.

The best meat was the  thinly splices of beef, not sure what the name was. They all started to mix together. I also ordered the spicy soft tofu soup with seafood. It was delicious. Silky tofu and a nicely flavored broth that was not too spicy.

While we were finishing up our meal, a man, perhaps an owner, stopped by and helped make sure we were doing well cooking our meats. He then came back a few minutes later to bring us 2 hot bowls of tofu soup. He noticed we had finished our white rice and brought us a new side of white rice to share. He insisted that we put some rice in the soup. It was so nice of him to do that and give it to us on the house. Totally unexpected and totally awesome.

It was pricey for what you get, but I would go back to try their other dishes aside from K-bbq!

Food is good and management is nice/helpful. Only complaint was that they were busy the night we went so we didn't get refills on drinks and had to wait a while for someone to check up on us.  Experience was good, overall.

The food was really good and the atmosphere was unique and makes you feel like you're in a small Korean village.The food was pretty good and the service was also ok. I had the bulgogi and thought it was pretty good, but I have problems finding a place that makes a terrific bulgogi, but this one wasn't bad.

My frustration was with the ventilation and service.  They seemed really busy and everyone was grilling something at their tables. The smoke permeated the air and I left the place with a strong food odor on my clothes.

As far as the service, because it was so busy, I found myself constantly asking for assistance. More water, drinks, a chance to order.. it just wasn't good.

I'd give them another chance, because I did like the atmosphere and the food was good, but if the service is still bad, I'll be moving on to another restaurant.

Tried Koreana for the first time today for lunch.  Another review had mentioned a lunch rush and specials for $5.95.  The lunch specials are now $7.99 (still not a bad value for what you get) and there was plenty of seating available.

The menu is limited at lunch time, only about 12 dishes, all for the same price, which come with soup and some additional appetizers such as kimchi and others that I am not well-versed enough with Korean food to identify.  My family enjoyed them, though.

I had the beef bulgogi, which while not being the best I've ever had, was certainly good enough to enjoy, if a little plain.  My wife loved the Bibimbap.

I would definitely come here again, but not all the time.

The pork bulgogi and bibimbap were absolutely delish--and so pretty to look at!  I watched food being cooked right on top of a neighboring table, which was fun.  The serving sizes were so huge that I would have needed to be rolled out of the restaurant if I had actually eaten everything.  With that being said, I would rather have a much smaller portion and lower price--it WAS lunch after all.  If I had been thinking straight, I would have just ordered ONE entree and shared it with my dining companion.  But I'm not sorry, since I got to sample two different dishes.  Anyway, I was very glad to have stopped at this little joint on my way back to Madison.  Thumbs up.

Had lunch with a long-time-no-seen friend here. Just walk in, no reservation needed, which is cool.

The grill/bbq is excellent, especially the bbq pork. It's been a while that I havn't had anything I can call it BBQ. _ or free appetizers are delicious as well. Too sad we only ordered two dishes. The environment is Korean-like but with TV in every conner to keep you attracted. Wow, this place is good.   
However, what is not good about this place is also fairly notable. The lady who took our orders is NOT very friendly. She went back-and-forth and was not helpful when we were struggling on which one to order. Moreover, she left us with the impression that people work at this awesome restaurant do not care what costumer's feeling. Too bad for a decent Korean Restaurant like this.

But anyway, for their good food, I will be back.
Only ate there once but it was extremely good!

My friend kept on insisting that I need to try this place because of their impeccable service and delicious food.  So finally after a friend's graduation, we decided to give this place a try.  We called ahead to reserve a table because we had a large group (thank goodness we did because it wasn't a huge place and it was getting busy).

As we walked in, we were immediately seated and offered water and tea.  My section of the group opted out of korean bbq and decided to order other things off the menu:

Appetizers:
- Seafood Pancake - mixed seafood w/ onions fried in a batter.  This is one of my favorite things to order in a Korean restaurant.  I don't know why, but something about all the flavors and textures makes it delicious.  Dip it in some homemade soy sauce for more flavor.
  
- Ddukbokki - sweet and spicy rice cake w/ squid,  fish cake and mix vegetables.  If you like spicy food, then this dish is for you.  All the flavors complimented each other well.  

Entrees:
- Kimchi Jjigae - spicy soup with kimchi, tofu, vegetables, and pork.  OMG...this was soo good.  It was spicy and the right amount of sour.

- Beef Chop Chae - clear noodles with beef and vegetables.  This dish did not stand out for me.  It was just average and taste like any other Korean place.

The food also came with a couple of side dishes.  It was not as much or as tasty as what I'm used to at other Korean restaurants.  But overall, I enjoyed this place.  The food was a little above average and the service here was great.  Definitely will consider coming back when I'm in the area again.

Lunch ends early whenever they feel like it, if they hand you a dinner menu, LEAVE.

PRICE INCREASE, only about a half dozen lunch specials are $8, the other half just got raised 10-25% and does pop them into that extra dollar sign.  
Korean BBQ much more expensive. Avoid peak times and that ENDLESS droning lunchtime reality real estate TV, yikes.

*Don't forget Viet House and Asian Noodle House do the same menu ALL day. HIGHLY recommended, Yu's unfortunately has really tanked for lunch.

the food is very authentic and the best part is the staff is very nice and friendly and accommodating.  Too often going to Korean, the language barrier, or the staff make it hard to just plain order.  Not at Koreana, everyone was very friendly nice, and most importantly the food was excellent!

On my quest to find Korean BBQ comparable to LA in the NW burbs, I have yet to. However this is the closest. Food is quality and service, because servers are generally younger, is better than most korean restaurants. This is my go to place.

so good. get here early or you won't get to cook your own.  there were five of us and we ordered two plan steaks to cook your own. and a couple of cold noodle soups to share (nangmeum).  they give you plenty of leaf lettuce to make wraps, use both sauces they give you. so good.  This is a meat dish, there is no rice.  when you are done, they use the hot pot to make kimchee fried rice!  they tossed in all the leftover ban chan and made some flavorful rice, and gave you a bowl of soup to eat it with.  so much food.  everything was fresh and good.
This place is amazing!! I've not tried the BBQ, but the Tofu, Pork, Kimchee dish on the sizzling platter is amazing, add the chap chae, and a beer and you are going to have a good night!

My group made reservations and boy am I glad we did. We went there on a Saturday night at 7 for dinner and it was packed. The signature meal here is grilling at your table. They'll bring you plates full of sliced meats and you cook them yourself. We got a combo platter, which had a good assortment of different things, including two large, whole shrimp. Its not very filling, but it is delicious! Their traditional Korean dishes are also great, so if you're looking for Korean but not necessarily bbq, then this place is still a must-go.

Great layout, great atmosphere and friendly service. Food comes out fresh and smoking hot (literally!) Nice little find. The staff is friendly and always on top of their game. They are quick and even quicker if you need them, push the little button on the wall by your table, it's magic powers will summon someone post haste to help you with whatever your needs be. 

The owner is a humble man who has no problem walking around greeting and chatting to everyone. Lovely place. It's good to step outside the regular places and venture into a new world like this. Like you fantastically stepped out and into a new country without the hassle of airplane tickets and the terrible tsa.

I ventured here on a Wednesday and it was packed and full of energy. Loved it.

I'd give this local korean joint a 3.5 stars. Not a 4 star cuz their Galbitang was a total disappointment & they ran out of hot barley tea! But i still love korean food :D


:: VENUE ::

Their prices were a bit higher than I would have expected to pay. But lucky us this one was on the company's expense~
The staff were really friendly and came by to check on us regularly. Huge difference since my last visit. The food came out fast and it was good
Amazing food and extremely friendly and super fast service. It was an amazing first time there!! Loved everything we had today! I would definitely come back to this place when I'm in town again!

Food is good and management is nice/helpful. Only complaint was that they were busy the night we went so we didn't get refills on drinks and had to wait a while for someone to check up on us.  Experience was good, overall.

The food was really good and the atmosphere was unique and makes you feel like you're in a small Korean village.The food was pretty good and the service was also ok. I had the bulgogi and thought it was pretty good, but I have problems finding a place that makes a terrific bulgogi, but this one wasn't bad.
