But when a place like Gianorio's comes along and is consistent, the staff caring, and the service impeccable it's really hard to dial a different number on pizza night. I always beat myself up for not finding this gem to order throughout my childhood. I wish I found it sooner, I probably would have won the lotto or something life changing. Not as life changing as when you arrive and the smell of success engulfs your nostrils at Gianorio's Pizza. If this is what love feels like, then I finally know how to love.

P.S. I know I always go back and forth between stuffed and double dough, but I can't help it. I think I love one more, but it's like Grandma Gianorio puts here love and care into both pizzas equally. I am not exaggerating either. My only gripe with this place is that I can't have it every single meal of every single day. I know that when these small business owners go on vacation and I am in town I panic like Americans did with Sputnik!

TAKE COVER AND FIND ANOTHER PIZZA PLACE. No thanks, I'd rather eat tin foil.

Dear Gionarios,

I grew up on Giordanos stuffed spinach pizza ...we had one down the street.  Since then  I've dabbled with Nancy's and Jakes stuffed spinach.  I am sure there was an unremarkable UNOs, Ginos and Malnati's in there somewhere. Really, none of them hold a candle to the stuffed spinach I got last night ...at Gianorios.  Chicagoans say that they hate stuffed pizza, but bring out-of-towners out to experience the treat.  Huh?  Yeah thin crust, flatbread and artisan pizzas are awesome, but nothing can take the place of a stuffed spinach pizza ...it's the real "pizza pie"

Troubling thing, is that I have driven past this place 2,00 times over the last 15 years, and never gave it a second thought.  Unfortunately, the whole mall has always been run-down looking, hidden behind other stores and has poor signage.  I even did a dry run an hour before pick up, because I was not sure where this place was.

How was I to know the best stuffed pizza ever resides here??

I digress ...

I typically do not write a review after only one visit, but here it is:

Ordered 12" stuffed spinach ...and sorry, I got sausage on it too:

The spinach stood out, and had great flavor
The sausage had that tasty pop of flavor, that you want
The sauce was amazing, truly the benchmark from which all other sauces should be measured
The crust? Crispy where you want, gooey where you want and there was a tasty char on it
Cheese ...well duh whats not to love about cheese?

My pizza was stuffed and I ate it until I was stuffed, with pizza.  No clue what double dough is or how their thin crust measures up to what I am used to ...but I will let you know!

Signed,
Customer for life

Absolutely. Incredible. Freaking. Pizza. Tonight was my first time trying Gianorio's Pizza with the fam. We usually head to Rosati's, Nancy's, or Lou's. I am definitely a pizza connoisseur. I've had pizza from everywhere...the East Coast, NY, hole in the wall places in Chicago, Uno's, Nancy's, Jakes, Giordano's, everywhere. 

I read the outstanding reviews about this place and we decided to give it a shot. Let me preface this by saying, it takes a lot for me to give a place five stars. I am a pretty harsh critic, particularly when it comes to sizing up the quality of a pie. I'm a pizza skeptic. 

So many things go into my consideration of a good pizza. Crust, sauce, cheese, toppings. Not to mention service and freshness. Gianorio's Pizza excelled in all these areas. We got a regular (thin crust) pizza with black olives, onions, and green peppers. The crust was a tad thicker than most thin crusts, but absolutely wonderful with just the right density and crunch, baked perfectly. The sauce was savory and tasty, with herbs and spices. The cheese was also sprinkled with herbs and there was plenty of it, cheese, that is. The toppings were plentiful, no scarcity, and the pizza was cooked to perfection and was hot and fresh. 

The service was also great, even though they were super busy. This is one thing I will say some other places in the area lack. They were prompt, efficient, and friendly. No mistakes and the pizza was ready right when they said it would be. 

We will definitely be coming here for our weekend pizza ritual from now on. The pizza is truly heaven on earth, can't wait to order from here again! I would definitely recommend Gianorio's Pizza for a fantastic, delicious, suburban pizza experience!

Sorry V&V, you've been ousted as my favorite.

The grandma still works in the kitchen.
The sausage is awesome.
The sauce is the best in area, and no heartburn afterwards.
Greasy, but not overly so.
The crust, it's unique. Well done still has a bit of a chew to it.
They know you by name.

Just try it. But just know that the hours are wonky.

Was looking for a new place after I had a horrible experience at Caliendo's in Winfield. I posted a review already from December. Anyways...if you blink going down County Farm Road, you may miss this place. Tucked away in a mini mall, is this wonderful place called Gianorio's. I called for a carry out order to try them out. Very nice people, very hospitable, and humble, and appreciative of the business. Told them of the bad experience at the other place and they said to let them know what I thought about their pizza. Brought it home and my wife asked if I requested extra sauce and extra cheese. I said no....but it sure looked as I did. I could feel how heavy the pizza was when I got it but wow....lots of ingredients. Flavor was awesome. Price was great. Great pie. I will be back!!!

We must give this a
 four star ...99% of the time our pizza is awesome .. 
Also, when they tell you what time you can pick your pizza up, it is ready and hot ..
You need to try their new deli on Winfield rd... 
My husband & I love our sweets, cannot pass up one of their homemade desserts..
You can purchase one & have plenty to split ...   They are pick up only  ..
One of the best pizzeria's in the western suburbs
Amazing pizza and friendly service!   The stuffed pizza is super dense and worth a try, our family is a big fan of the regular pizza and probably orders twice a month at a minimum!
Our favorite local pizza place. Friendly staff and great regular crust pizza. If there's some red velvet cupcakes from their sister store (Gianarios cafe) pick them up!

Well, after my initial review, I decided to give Gianorio's a second chance. Good god was that a smart move! I made them repeat my order, so they got it right. When I grabbed my box of stuffed pizza, it was heavier than a phone book! When it came to the taste, it was incredible. The cheese is perfect, the sauce is amazing, and the pepperoni incredible. I'm not a big fan of the crust though, I still prefer Malnati's crust because it's buttery and they use corn meal. I will definitely be making Gianorio's one of my go-to joints for stuffed pizza. I'm glad I gave them a second chance, and I HIGHLY recommend it to anyone considering going!
Just ate there for the first time tonight. The pizza was as good as yelp said! We got a medium which was perfect for two big eaters.
The best. Period. The sauce to cheese ratio is unrivaled. The jumbo red velvet cupcakes are nothing short of heavenly as well.

After reading all of the reviews for the stuffed pizza, I will have to try it soon. I've only ever had thin crust at Gianorio's, and it has never disappointed in the many years I've been going. Mmmm pizza!!!

Their pizza is DELICIOUS. You get a lot for your money: recently ordered a 4 topping medium thin crust pizza at ~$20 and I swear the thing weighed over 10 lbs. My one critique is that the wait for a pizza is a little ridiculous at over 1:15 when I ordered on a Friday - might be because their pizza is in high demand!

Great pizza some of the best crust I have ever had! Pizza did cause a lot of heartburn in our house later on though! Really bad hours! So make sure you are not ordering to late. The hours are really only accommodating to the owners. We did get the wrong pizza last time we went there so we haven't gone back but it is always good!

Had the deep dish and regular crust pizzas... The deep dish was fantastic, among the best deep dish I've ever had! The regular crust is also a winner, has a delightful crunch but not over doing it. Would definitely recommend this place!

OK, I haven't had Gianorio's pizza in...over a decade? I still remember how good it was. 

I actually worked here when I was in high school - was the doughboy around 1997 - 1998, so if you ate at this place back then, I probably rolled out your pizza! This place is the real deal. Everything about it is good, starting with the actual pizza, and including the owners (does the same family still own / run it?). 

Anyway, I've had pizza all over the world, and I live in NYC now, but for me, Gianorio's will always be the way pizza is supposed to be.

Such a great hidden pizza place!! I've been going to Gianarios since I can remember and I've never gotten a pizza there that wasn't amazing. If you're anywhere close to Winfield I recommend trying giving them a call. You will not be disappointed!!
Miss my days in the kitchen!

This is why we love Yelp. We just moved to the area, and wanted to find a local pizza place to try. Based on other yelpers, we tried Gianorios. It is fantastic! Just like other reviewers have said, Grandma literally works in the kitchen, she was making pizza dough the day we picked up the pizza.

And oh, the pizza. It's wonderful. High quality toppings (we had a 6-topping combo, and a sausage/pineapple/garlic pizza, and a sausage/pepperoni), the sauce is sweet and not too acidic, and the crust is great. Just all around awesome pizza, first place we've found that we like better than Gino's East.

And man, you really really have to get the Carrot cake, we will stop by after school now just to pick up some dessert.

lastly, a few older reviews say cash only, but they DO now accept visa and mastercard.

I have had pizza all over Chicagoland.  Grew up in the city with Gino's, Uno's, Home Run Inn, Giordano's, etc.  Have had pizza from every little place in the Western Suburbs and this place is hands down the best.

i have had it for several of my parties and now people from 25 miles away come out here to pick up this pizza.  I discovered this place when they first opened in 1988 and I had just moved about a mile away and have been going back ever since.  

In 24 years of pizza, every pizza has been fantastic.  And believe me, that is alot of pizza to get right. 

A couple of weeks ago, had a taste testing party against Al's Pizza in Warrenville.  Their pizza was really good, but Gianorio's was the unequivocal winner.

Keep up the Good Work Guys.  Also, love, love, love the Pepper and Egg sandwiches at the Downtown Deli.  Put them on the menu for every Friday.

Selene M.
I have had Gianorios a few times since my 1st review, and its just as unbelievable and tasty. Honestly, hands down, the best pizza ever!!!!!

Best pizza around in the western suburbs.  Cheesy garlic bread not bad, The red velvet cupcakes are great.  Service is great, price is average. Only down fall is they dont have delivery.  Would order here alot more if delivery was an option.

A quiet little tablecloth Italian place with a few outside tables and views of both the railroad crossing and firehouse. We had the thin crust pizza which had a tasty cracker crust topped with tangy, sweet sauce and quality cheese. It was delicious and one of the best pizzas I've had in a while.
Lived here for 20 years.  This is the best pizza in the burbs.

Don't know what has happened, as I had frequented this pizza place often, but got a pizza, cheese only, and it REEKED so bad of onion, I couldn't even eat it!

They lost my business....

This is a great family pizza place.  Take out only, no dine in and no delivery.  They are not open for lunch and they only take cash or checks.  They have regular crust pizza, pan pizza, stuffed pizz and GREAT calzones.  Everything is fresh and very tasty.

They also have a 18 inch jumbo pizza which can be hard to find.  It works great for us with all these boys!

EXCELLENT pizza!  The first time I picked up our order from here I hadn't realized that they also had desserts available - but that was ok, because they've got some available when you pick up your pizza.  The pizza itself is great - nice amount of cheese and toppings.  When we moved to this area we just ordered from the closest pizza place - but after talking to several other Winfield residents, Gianorios was always mentioned as the place to get pizza.  I definitely agree with the other posters that this is the best pizza in the area!

Best pizza in DuPage, hands down.  Dough is made from scratch, sauce is made from fresh-packed tomatoes, and the people working there are as nice as they come.  Pick up only, no delivery, no credit cards, closed Mondays and Tuesdays.  I recommend trying their calzones,they are spectacular.

This has been our go-to pizza place for a couple of years now. We wander away on occasion but always come back and wonder why we ever tried anywhere else. They can miss sometimes. I swear it's when Mama is not in the kitchen. Tonight we had the classic and a cheese and sausage and Mama was in house. It was just as five stars says: as good as it gets. The sauce has flavor. The dough is not too thin, not too thick, the toppings are generous and seasoned nicely. Only problem is the long wait on Friday nights. Always think we are going to order early but somehow don't.

Best pizza place ever!  Pan pizza is all I get, but I wouldn't get it anywhere else.  The sauce is sweet/savory.  The cheese is melty/buttery.  The crust is doughy and wonderful!  The owners are awesome people!!  Only thing, I wish they were open more often...but even perfection needs sleep.

Without a doubt, the best pizza in Wheaton/Winfield area. Great pasta and homemade desserts. An example of a well-run family business.
Take-out only. Wed.-Sun only

Probably the best option in Winfield/Wheaton.  VERY easy to miss this place due to its size (carry-out only) but don't pass it up.  Great crust and even better sauce make this a staple for me.  I recommend the regular crust pepperoni.  The home-made lemon bars and brownies are a good palette cleanser.  Credit not accepted.  Thumbs up !

cannot stop drinking the broth.

i can die a happy man because I have experienced ramen heaven.

This place is just ok. Way to much hype. The restaurant is really small and most likely you will have to wait a bit before being seated. We were eventually sat at the bar, shoulder to shoulder. My face was about 4 inches from the soup bowl. I had broth steaming my face to the point that I wiped my forehead with a napkin. By the time I was done eating I smelled like dried seaweed and green onions. 

 I've had significantly better ramen at Santouka Ramen inside Mitsua Market.

This was my second time having been to this delicious place! I love ramen, and have been spoiled with Santouka at Mitsuaw growing up. While I love this place, I still find Santouka's flavors to be better. 

I tried the miso ramen yesterday, which is always what I get at Santouka. I liked this ramen a lot, however I wished there were a couple slices of pork; I only received one slice of pork which had a lot of fat on it, which was nice for flavor but I just would've liked a little more pork. I might be spoiled with the 3 slices I get from Santouka's miso! The broth is excellent and the egg perfectly soft boiled. For an appetizer we split the gyoza, which were very big in size, with an excellent filling; would definitely order this again. 

We arrived at 6:11, and they open at 6. I kid you not every table had been taken in those 11 minutes they were open, that should tell you something about how great this place is. We were lucky to get three seats at the bar! 

My cousin noticed towards the end of our dinner that there were pretty definite lipstick on my glass; I wish I would've seen it sooner as I would've simply asked for a new glass. I was drinking on the side of the lipstick and I honestly don't know how I didn't see it but it did grossed me out once I'd  noticed. However, I understand that lipstick is sometimes hard to get off and this will not prevent me from coming here again as I do love the food, however I will just double check our glasses the next time I visit!

'twas the only rainy day in chicago so ramen seemed like the appropriate food for lunch.

stopped by ramen house shinchan and wow, where did all these japanese speaking japanese people come from?!  i assume there must be a supplier / japanese company nearby.

i really wanted to try the taiwan ramen (since you know, i'm taiwanese and all), but decided to go with the "best condition ramen" since i wanted veggies.  

i was served the biggest bowl of ramen i've ever seen, so big that i only ate half and got the rest to go.  the stir fried veggies were delicious topped on top of the ramen.  

the broth was a little too salty for my liking, but great flavor profile.  

owned and operated by japanese.  totally legit.

I came here after church a few weeks ago with my boyfriend and I was expecting a long wait since I saw a bunch of people waiting to be seated but it took only about 15-20 minutes to be seated. The workers don't say much but it's not really that they're rude, more of them trying to be efficient. Their menu is pretty simple and nothing too fancy which is not necessarily a bad thing. I ordered the Best-Condition Ramen and my boyfriend ordered the Taiwan Ramen. I have to admit, for the price, you get a lot. I've gotten more for my money here compared to any other ramen place I've been to but I just didn't LOVE the broth. For me, the most important part of ramen is the broth but it was just good/okay. I still have to say that it was worth the money and I would definitely come back.

We love the ramen here.  For appetizer, we ordered:
     - Calamari 
       The breading is very light and not greasy.
     - Tebasaki 
       Baked chicken wings
     - Karage

For ramen, we ordered:
     - Shio-ramen
     - Tonkotsu-ramen 
        The broth is really flavorful.

We get there at 11 A.M. and the place opens at 11:30 A.M.  There is already a line.  At 11:35 A.M., the place is full.  Seating is limited but there is ample parking.

There's nothing like a bowl of noodle soup on a cold day and the ramen here certainly hits the spot.  This restaurant is on the small size, so be prepared to wait for a table if you come during peak hours.  They don't take reservations, so we dropped by to put our name in for dinner on a Saturday night.  They quoted us a 45 minute wait time and gave us a pager and was willing to call our cell phone.  We left and came back within 45 minutes and true to their words, our table was ready!  

Tonkotsu Ramen $10.75 - I love this ramen because of its creamy broth.  The noodles were nice and chewy.  It's tough paying this much for noodle soup, but it still beats Chicago prices and it was delicious!

They have many other ramen flavor and styles to choose from, including shoyu ramen, shio ramen, Taiwan ramen (spicy), miso ramen, vegetarian, and curry.  Besides ramen, they offer chicken wings, pork cutlets, gyoza, fried rice, yaki soba, calamari, soft shell crab and assorted other appetizers.

I'm the kind of person that's ALWAYS in the mood for ramen-- so when I heard this place was pretty close to where I live, I was curious to try.. and yes, the ramen here is good!! 

I came here with my family (there were 4 of us) on a Thursday night around 7pm. The restaurant itself isn't that big, so there was a bit of a wait. About 15 minutes later, our buzzer went off and we got seated right away. 

We took a look at the menu while we were waiting, so our server was able to take our orders right away. Our food arrived no more than 10 minutes. I ordered the Taiwan-Ramen since I wanted something spicy, my sister and dad ordered the famous Tonkatsu ramen, and my mom ordered the one with seafood (can't remember the name). We ordered the chicken wings as well. 

The broth was SO good, and the quality of the noodles was probably my favorite part. You can tell that they were fresh noodles, not the dry ones that need to be rehydrated. Also, the soups were served at the perfect temperature: hot, but not piping hot. 

Taiwan-Ramen: According to reviews, this is supposed to be SUPER spicy. I have a pretty high tolerance to spicy foods, so it wasn't THAT spicy to me, but it was still very good! Noticed it was very heavy on the ground pork and bean sprouts, and didn't come with that much noodles. The broth was very savory and had a nice kick. 

Tonkatsu Ramen: The hype is real! The broth is very savory and you can really taste the pork in the broth-- yum! This one had a generous amount of noodles but the pork slices were OK. I would definitely order this for the next time I'm there 

Seafood Ramen (forgot the name): It was good; definitely a lot lighter than the other two. Had lots of toppings and was probably the least salty out of the three. 

Fried Chicken: SO good! The pieces look like they're dry rubbed with seasonings, but it actually it lightly glazed with a sweet, but savory, sauce. It wasn't drenched in sauce (which is my pet peeve unless it's buffalo wings), and it was both crispy and juicy. Would definitely order again next time. 

Again, I'll definitely be back. I still would choose Santouka in Mitsuwa over this place, but this comes in #2 as far as Ramen houses in the Suburbs.

We thought the food was tasty but not quite so spectacular as others.  The shio-ramen was a bit salty, tonkatsu-ramen was more flavorful, and the sara-uson was the best of the bunch.

Be aware that the place is quite small and so popular that on a Saturday afternoon at 2 pm we waited 25 minutes for a table.

Stopped by again this Saturday evening. We got there about 5 minutes after 5PM opening, and we were able to score the second to last table. They still had some counter seats left too.

We ordered Gyoza and Kara-age again, and they were excellent!  
On this trip we decided to try the Curry Rice with Pork Katsu instead of having Ramen. The dish was outstanding!  It was as good as any I've had in Japan.

Service was fast and friendly too.

Very much like pure Japanese ramen shop! They have variety of ramens and few sides.

I and husband were lucky only waiting for 15 minutes and got seats at counter around 1:30pm on Saturday. The new party just came in was told that it would be 45 mins!

I got best condition ramen which was spicy and lots of vegetables!! which I love! It is very hard to balance the noodle and vegetables when it comes to ramen, but here it comes! Volume of the ramen was just too much though. 

My husband got Tonkotsu. It was creamy and good. The type of noodle was differed by the soup which is very rare around this area. I can see their passion about ramen. Side; Negi was too spicy and bitter to finish all. 

Overall, I like my best condition ramen, tasty right textured noodle and lots of fresh vegetables! However, $30 for 2 ramen and 1 side was too expensive when considering "ramen house." I think they should make smaller bowls of ramen and lower the price. 

I personally prefer Daruma Japanese restaurant's Tonkotsu ramen much better than here because it lacks the sophisticated taste of soup and broth here. Maybe it's designed for typical American guys. Not enough for foodie Japanese people. I probably come back when it has less waiting time.

I SOOOO wanted to LOVE this place, but it just didn't appeal to my palette that day! I went in with a group of regulars who RAVE about this place. We ordered the Kara-age and I had the miso ramen. My husband had the spicy pork rice bowl and the others had the miso ramen or another rice bowl. 

Those of us who got the miso ramen didn't really care for it. Remember, the people I was with have had it before. For some reason, it was really bland that day. It just didn't taste good. SO SAD!!! The kara-age was really good. You definitely need the pepper/mayo with it! :) 

The service is great. Everyone was really nice and quick. It's the reason I gave Ramen House Shinchan 3 stars...otherwise it would've been 2 (based solely on the miso ramen I ordered). 

Would I go back? Sure! I won't be getting the miso ramen though...it left a bad taste in my mouth. :( Ugh, and I love miso!!!
Do yourself a favor and get the Best Condition Ramen. It is a little spicy, has lots of garlic and tons of stir fry veggies on top. The best (condition)!

This is my second time coming here and did not disappoint me at all. Both ramen and curry rice was really good. Karage was decent as well.  The place is small but i think that's the charm of it! As long as you arrive past the busy dinner time, it won't be a big wait as you would think..

I've gone back a few times since my original review and in all fairness I definitely need to bump up my rating. When I first tried this place, I honestly wasn't impressed. In fact, it was one of my lowest rated ramen reviews despite getting all the love from that article in the Chicago Tribune. As I said in my first review, I loved the broth, liked the noodles, but hated the unappetizing, grey pieces of pork that came in the tonkotsu. While I still think the pork is lacking in so many ways, the broth is consistently good and I was able to find a few other awesome items on the menu that make me forget about the lackluster slices of pork. 

Taiwan Meat - This was the game changer for me. You can instantly take any of their bowls of ramen to the next level for a mere $2. Highly suggest it. It's basically a decent size bowl of ground pork and huge cloves of garlic, drowned in some sort of chili oil. For anyone who's left wanting more after seeing only 1 or 2 strips of meat in their ramen, this is the solution. Plus, it adds an amazing garlicky spice. When you combine the Taiwan meat with the tonkotsu broth...game over dude. When that milky broth turns orange, it's on. 

Tonkotsu Ramen - See my original review for the details. The broth was creamy, salty, and super porky. The noodles were thin and al dente, and the soft boiled egg was perfect for me: moist and gelatinous, but not completely runny. The cha shu pork was unfortunately bland.

Tebasaki wings - An order came with 5 wings. They weren't the typical overly sauced, sweet and spicy Asian glazed wings that you see everywhere. Instead, the skin was soft but still with a broiled type texture on the outside. There wasn't a sauce but rather a salt/pepper looking rub. Really tasty.

Gyoza - Seared nice and crispy on the outside and the inside had juicy meat. Pretty standard.

Karaage - Lightly breaded chicken with a delicious mayo and salt/pepper blend on the side. It wasn't as crispy as I was expecting but the meat was still very juicy. TIP: I would suggest getting the small because the large costs twice as much but didn't seem like it had twice the quantity. 

Drinks: Shinchan seems like a business lunch type place. Most people come in to get their ramen fix and are back on their way shortly after. It didn't seem like a happy hour environment where people just sit around, drink, and get rowdy. Well...that didn't stop us from trying haha. The only alcoholic drinks they had were Japanese beer, and one type of sake that came in a jar. Sounds like sake bombs to me! A few of these and you're good to go.

Overall, Ramen House Shinchan has quickly become my go to ramen spot in the burbs. Sorry I ever doubted you guys...

Lately, we've been seeking out ramen... The boy got a hankering for it and there aren't any places near us that offer it. He was unconvinced that I wouldn't find a place within reasonable distance that would serve us up a good bowl! Challenge accepted! Just 20 minutes away I found this little place that served us the best ramen ever! You should go... Go now!

I ordered the Chapon Ramen which was filled with Egg Noodles in Pork Broth with seafood, pork and vegetables.  This was a combination that the boy frowned at as he's not into seafood; however, it was absolutely fantastic! The broth was rich and complemented the seafood, scallops and shrimp, better than one would expect! The boy tried it, sans seafood, and admitted it was quite tasty! And I had leftovers for 2 days of lunch!

The boy ordered the Miso Ramen which had Egg Noodles in a Miso-based Pork broth with braised Pork, soft-boiled Egg and Vegetables. The miso went nicely with the tender pork and veggies. The boy only likes certain veggies, so I ended up with some of them! The egg was delish and I ordered one for myself!

For sides and apps we ordered...

Gyoza which is a Pork and Vegetable Dumpling. These were better than any pork dumplings we've gotten at a takeout place! The wrapping was thin and well-cooked instead of thick and weird. The meat inside was well seasoned and tasty!

Fried Rice with Egg, Scallions, chopped Pork and Fish Cake. This was really good fried rice especially compare to what we've gotten via takeout! No added sauces needed! Well done!

We'll definitely be back! Their staff was super friendly and attentive! Even the other patrons were nice and understanding that they get so busy!

We went on a Thursday night and it wasn't too crowded. I ordered my favorite Tonkatsu ramen and a large order of friend chicken. Both are very good and Japanese style. The authentic ramen broth can be a little bit on the salty side and it was. I appreciate it because it tasted very thick and flavorful. The noodles were cooked just right as well. I would definitely plan to go back and try other dishes. 
I heard about the long wait in the weekends and I would say i won't wait for more than one hour for it though. It's a pretty small place maybe with up up 50 seats. Service is good as well.

Many of my friends and co-workers are big ramen fans, so I've spent a considerable amount of effort trying out many of the top ramen places in Chicago (Strings, Ramen Misoya, Santouka, Sozai Banzai, etc.). I had heard many great things about Ramen House Shinchan before coming here and had actually visited several times before I actually ate here this last visit. Previously, I would go relatively early for lunch but end up going elsewhere due to the long wait to get a seat. This time, I got there 20 minutes before they opened and fortunately was able to be seated soon after opening time (the line to get in at opening was about equal to the total number of seats available in the restaurant).

Overall, I had high expectations for the food from what I heard from others. My actual experience was pretty good -- the food was enjoyable, not mind blowing in terms of flavor or creativity -- but it was prepared well, colorful, served quickly, and had simple flavors. I wish the non-ramen dishes could've been prepared better and that there could've been more depth of flavor in each component of the ramen though. Here were my thoughts on the items I tried.

Chahan - A bit on the salty side, really lacking in flavor from the scallions and a very small hint of egg flavor (which I think is almost essential to any fried rice). The pork was also a bit tough and the fish cake barely added any flavor. Nice contrast of textures but wasn't a fan of the flavors.

Tebasaki - Enjoyable chicken wings with nice tender meat. A bit strong on the seasonings though as you'll get a good kick of sweetness and saltiness at the same time with a strong kick of pepper while you taste soy sauce and rice wine adding a bit of flavor depth. 

Kara-age - Chicken was tender and juicy but I wish the batter had been fried a bit more. 

Shio Ramen - The egg noodle is a bit more firm than what many may expect, but that's normal for this type of noodle. The soft boiled egg is done very well and does mix well with the braised pork which is soft, tender, and just slightly salty. The clear chicken broth does feel healthy but really is a bit light on flavor. The additional of a few additional components such as seaweed or seafood could've added much greater flavor to the broth.

Chanpon Ramen - Fish cake, pork, and vegetables in a creamy pork broth with medium firmness noodle. This tastes pretty similar to the seafood noodle soup preparations you'll find in finer Chinese and Korean noodle restaurants. The cabbage did bring out a good amount of sweetness but I wish that the shrimp was a little larger and that the vegetable mix was a bit more premium. 

Tonkotsu Ramen - This seems to be the dish that everyone raves about. It does have a nice flavorful broth with soft egg noodles and braised pork that is very tender (but could really use additional seasonings). The entire dish does have a creamy feel to it with very strong themes of pork bone and meat. I wasn't blown away by it however -- as the only component that differentiated this ramen from others was the quality of the broth. There is still room for improvement to really elevate this to a special-trip worthy bowl.

Overall, the food is enjoyable but really not worth a special trip if you don't already live in the suburbs and have to wait a long time for a seat.

Came here around 1:30pm on a Sunday. The place was packed! We had to wait 30min for a party of 6. The place is tiny, so not a lot of room for waiting around. At one point my friends and I were standing outside in the cold since it was too crowded inside. One of the Japanese servers there does not know English very well - I took it as a sign of authenticity. 

I had the Miso Ramen. The broth is just ok...was disappointed a little bit cuz there wasn't a strong miso taste. But the slice of pork that I had was very good, same with the egg. 

I had a taste of the Tonkatsu ramen. It was so good that I wish i had gotten that. The broth was very flavorful. Definitely worth trying the next time. My friend also ordered the fried chicken for our table to share. Oh my! It was very good. It was so juicy that some of it squirted out when I took my first bite. The meat was very well seasoned. I'll surely get that next time I visit. This place is indeed a gem in the Chicago suburb!

LITERALLY the best Ramen I've had.  Pork broth....

It's worth it.

I've bookmarked this ramen place for a long time and finally I had a chance stopping by the area to check it out on a weekend for lunch. It has a similar setup as Reman Misoya in Mount Prospect - located in a rundown strip mall with not many seating inside. It was packed and a couple of parties were waiting - a good sign. I got seated right away because I was just by myself. 

I had the Tonkotsu ramen. The portion was just right. I liked the simple toppings they had - mung bean sprout,  a soft boiled egg, green onion and the meat (unlike the corn, potato wedges and the other stuff Ramen Misoya added to the their noodle, which I don't really care for). The first couple spoonful of the broth had me wowed. The noodle was so fresh and was just so good. The disappointment came from the piece of pork. It's a bit on the tough side, not tender as I'd expected. Then the more I ate, it became saltier to the taste. The egg was flavored as well, which was not bad but added more saltiness to the dish. I so wished I could empty the bowl because all the other rich flavors were there, but I couldn't.

It could be just me though, as I usually perfer dishes easy on salt. The elder Japanese lady patron next to me had the same thing as mine and she finished the  whole thing. 

So overall, it's good ramen. Service was great as well. But my most favorite ramen so far is still Santouka in Mitsuwa. Anyway, I would come back to try the other noodle dishes next time when I'm in the area.
Wow The broth is out of this world. Authentic as it gets around here

This place is great for some authentic ramen. It definitely hits the spot on a cold night. I got the tonkotsu ramen. The broth was creamy and white which I was surprised to see but it didn't taste like dairy. It had a really nice pork flavor to the broth and was perfectly seasoned, not overly salty. The noodles were fine but nothing out of the ordinary. There was one fatty piece of pork which was perfect for my liking and the egg was amazing.

My friend and I also shared the fried chicken which tasted great. it was fried and seasoned just right. The servers were very friendly, attentive, and quick which was good because there were a lot of customers there. We lucked out because we got there 2 minutes before it opened at 5pm so we were able to get a table with no wait. I would suggest going with a group no more than 4. Overall, this is a great place to grab a hot tasty bowl of ramen with friendly service.

Absolutely amazing! Not only did the ambiance make me feel like I was back in Japan but the food was delicious. I had the ramen with char siu. The pork could have been a bit more BBQ' on the outside but otherwise it was really good!

This is a legitimate ramen house in the burbs. We came during lunch hour, and it was fairly busy (though there was absolutely no wait for us). We were immediately seated at a two-seater table and given our menus. They have a lot to choose from, so I'll have to come back and try some of their other ramens and dishes (particularly the chicken karaage). 

My boo ordered the tonkotsu ramen, which comes in a rith pork broth, barisedpork belly, a soft boiled egg, scallions and bean sprouts. This is the type of broth and ramen noodles you would look for in tonkotsu ramen. The broth was savory, the noodles were cooked well, and the pork was decent (not the best I've had, some are like melt-in-your-mouth sexy goodness). 

I ordered the Best Condition ramen, and the first thing I thought of when it came out was "holy mother of veggies, batman!" Yes, there's a lot of stir-fried vegetables on top, with plenty of sprouts (my fav) and lots of garlic pieces (probably too much, but it did wonders to the broth flavor). This comes in a chicken based broth, but was still pretty savory. Not as rich as the pork, which is what I seem to prefer, but the spiciness was nice and refreshing.

It was fine, I just don't think I am a ramen person and I really do not like fatty pieces of meat.  I'm sure it added flavor to the broth, but I really don't like to deal with it. Didn't mind the wait, staff are really nice and quick.

This place is authentic and great. Only issue is that it is so small and in a random strip mall. I guess that adds to the feeling of authenticity, but it makes it tricky to stop in with more than a couple of people. We came with a group of five, and squeezed into a 4-top after waiting more than 30 minutes (despite not much of a line in front of us). We'll come back and will consider pick-up.

The service at this place is EXCEPTIONAL. Man, they are so quick! Like I was reaching in my purse to get my wallet and I made eye contact with a waiter that didn't even serve us, and 2 seconds later we got our check - quick AF. We went on a thursday night and it was pretty filled. They only had 1 empty table for 2. But even then, people came and when people were done, more people came. Anyways, let's talk about the food.

Tonkatsu Ramen: according to fellow Yelpers, this was a pretty popular dish. Let's talk about the ramen itself. There's a lot. Like a lot of it. I kept eating and it felt like it wasn't ending. Okay I'm exaggerating but it's definitely more ramen than all the places I've been to. It had a good bite to it, so nicely all dente. The broth wasn't as rich as I had hope. It's still rich but I think because they put so much bean sprouts in that it diluted the broth. It wasn't too salty at first, but when you continue eating it gets saltier. The chashu, the sad sad one piece chashu. It wasn't a huge piece and there was nothing special about it. It just makes me sad. But I still ate it.

Miso Ramen: you can taste and smell the miso from the broth, but again I feel like the veggies (cabbage and bean sprouts) overpowered the flavor of the miso itself. The ramen is different from the tonkatsu. It's more yellow and it's the spiral ones. Personally, I like these better because it "feels" more ramen to me lol but it doesn't have that chewy bite like the other ramen for the tonkatsu. That doesn't mean the ramen is overcooked. It had a good texture to each bite. Same, sad one piece of chashu in this one too *sigh*

Fried chicken wing: it had a good crisp to the bite. The seasoning is good, but a bit on the saltier side. But I kept wanting to eat it because the color looks good. It's like the perfect colored chicken wings sprinkled with black peppers.

Wow this place is deeeelicious! Got the tankatsu Ramen bowl and it was huge. Lotsa fresh ramen noodles in a pork broth with hard boiled egg, bean sprouts, and pork. 
The place was packed for lunch but service was efficient and friendly and didn't feel like they rushed you at all. 
This place is a definite return destination! Try it you'll love it!

Finding a place to eat in the burbs at 11p at night that isn't fast food or drunk food is nearly impossible. Lo and behold Ramen House was to the rescue!!  

The owner greeted us immediately as we walked in and was very friendly. The place is very clean, brightly lit and modern. The menu has other items for non-ramen eaters. Keep an eye out on their chalkboard for specials.  We ordered the chicken wings, Tiwan ramen and Shio ramen. The food came out quickly, which is something I like. We've been to other ramen places where you're waiting an eternity for your food. Don't mess with a girl who is hangry!! 

The Tiwan ramen was spicy, meaty, filing and down right delicious. It had a enough heat to give it a kick but without burning your mouth. The Shio was smooth, light and complemented the other ingredients very well. As for those wings, we made the right choice ordering them. The wings had a nice crispy finish without being over cooked or oily. Needless to say we were happily in a food coma and fell right asleep when we got home. Now I've a reason to come out to the burbs more often!!

Wow. A Ramen House this good in Palatine? Who would have thought.

There were six in our party, and the restaurant is small. Maybe they have ten or twelve tables. Luckily, we only waited about ten minutes before they had a table ready for us. We ordered gyoza to start, these were great - sauted enough to be crisp, yet soft and chewy inside. Tasty.

The service was fast and we received our ramen before we finished the gyoza. I had the Taiwan Ramen, which was spicy with ground pork (lots), green onion and herbs of various kinds. And, man was it spicy. I love spicy foods but know it's really spicy when my eyes water. And they did.

The only think I found curious was they did not offer hot tea. They offer a variety of soft drinks. They have canned iced tea (?). I stuck with water. While this was disappointing, the food and experience were both good. Had they offered hot tea I think my review would have given them five stars. 

If the owners read this, please take this as a suggestion. But regardless of their beverages, I'll be back.
Yessss. Simply tasty and expertly prepared ramen. Nothing extra trendy or funky here, not trying too hard. Traditional, clean, and just right :)
The food there is delicious, especially the chicken wings!
I just got the curry udon takeout and it is sooo good! Such a great combination, I can't wait to come back here.

ramen lovers in the burbs - this is the stop on your list. 

If I lived closeby, I would be a regular.  It is my question to try every dish on the menu.  

Totally authentic and easy on the pocket book.   

This place gets busy, so a good idea to arrive just at opening for lunch dn then for dinner as well.   They close midday for break.  

The toppers could be a good idea for more than one person as the size is quite good.   The Scallion topper with meat is lacking in meat but serves as almost like a nice salad to go along with the soup.  

Chicken Karagge is well flavored and crispy.  The single order was good enough to share. 

I had the best condition ramen which is an all vegetarian garlic bonanza of a ramen bowl.   Features stir fried veggies, garlic and some sweat inducing heat. It's absolutely great for a cold day!  

lots of regulars frequent the restaurant and its only been open about a year.   Join on in on the eat the entire menu club!  See ya there!
Cant believe this is in the suburbs!! There is vegetarian option too. I am fan!

Alien had small karaage, dumplings, shoyu ramen, and tonkotsu ramen. Each was good and reasonably priced. 

Shoyu ramen: 
Nothing very unique, but this is THE good shoyu ramen.
Very standard Japanese shoyu ramen soup with thick egg noodles.Alien could tell flavors of broth. Toppings (braised pork, bamboo shoots, green onions, and bean sprouts) were also simple but went great with the soup. The egg was perfectly cooked.  

Tonkotsu ramen: 
Very thin noodles. The soup was very creamy, standard Japanese tonkotsu ramen.
Some tonkotsu ramen can smell badly due to pork borns, but this ramen just had good flavors. Yum yum! 
 
Karaage: 
Freshly-fried and very juicy! And reasonable price for this amount of karaage. Alien love flavors of the yummy powder (salt & Japanese pepper). It was a bit oily though. Alien prefer more crispy karaage. 

Dumplings: 
Very standard Japanese fried dumpling with thin dough skins. As yummy as dumplings Alien used to have in Japan. The sauce was yum yum! 
It was a bit sad that some dumplings had broken skin though.

This place was packed which is always a good sign. They have a pretty tiny menu but their ramen is fantastic. They put plenty into the bowls and the broth is really makes the entire thing worth it. I would have had two bowls but you have to show some self control.

I was surprised to find an authentic ramen restaurant in this part of IL. I think the staff spoke in Japanese, though they can potentially be Taiwanese as well. 

Food: 
Ordered a Shio ramen. Noodles had a nice bouncy texture. Soup was good. Decent bowl of ramen. 

Service: 
Very friendly staff.

Environment: 
Sat by the bar area which is exactly how I my ramen served. 

Price: 
Decently priced. 

Food: 4
Service: 4
Environment: 5
Price: 4

This place is very busy if your coming with a group bigger than 2 plan to wait 15 minutes on a good day and 30+ minutes on a busy day which seems like everyday.  Luckily for me I had the time to go and this place myself.  The place itself has about 6ish tables maybe more I don't quite remember.  Then it has the bar seats which fits about 10 ppl so about 40-50 ppl total at one time. 

I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen and the broth was good and rich. Not to overwhelming where you can't drink it and the ramen noodles are the straight ones so that is a plus. I always prefer the straight ramen noodles compared to the wavy ones.  

They always have a lot of bean sprouts for some reason. I don't like a lot but some people do. The egg is a nice taste good much like a small flavor just enough so that it's not salty or super sweet. The pork is also very good but the amount you receive is small compared to other ramen places that is why it lost one star.

Aside from its overwhelming popularity and long waits due to minimal competition in the burbs,
Shinchan is pretty awesome. 

The items on their menu are reasonably priced and delicious. The ramen noodles are perfectly prepared with enough chewiness. The broths are flavorful, yet not too rich. The eggs are soft-boiled well. The meat could use some upgrading, but it isn't bad. The appetizers are decent as well.

Tip: Don't come during prime hours.

I waited to review this place till I went a few times. I have to say that consistency is something that the Ramen House has nailed down. While I have only had the Taiwan Ramen it is consistently excellent. I have taken people from work here and all of them enjoyed their various ramens. I even got my wife to try it and she enjoyed it as well. The dumplings here are delicious. If you really like spicy I highly recommend trying the Taiwan Ramen. I also suggest ordering a couple eggs with it as well. They really pair well with the spicy broth. 

The only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars is due to the price. While I will admit that you do get filled up on an order, I just don't see how noodles and broth with a little bit of meat can cost $12 with tax. 

This won't stop me from going back again in the future, but that's the only bad thing I could really say about this restaurant. 

One thing I want to point out is that this place is tiny. It only holds 35 people so I highly recommend take out. It's not uncommon to drive by and see a line out the door. 

Best part for me about this place is that it's open till midnight on the weekends and 11:00 during the week. I hope this place is starting a new trend for all suburban restaurants to follow. Nothing is worse than being hungry late at night and no place is open other than fast food chains. 

I will be going back and I highly recommend giving this place a try.

Update: I now frequent this place about once a week. I have tried nearly every item on the menu. My favorite dishes are the chicken wings, the Taiwan Ramen (with a soft boiled egg) and the best condition ramen. Yes, I do enjoy spicy food, but that's not why I picked these dishes. I just felt that the flavors were the best in these Ramens. The wings are just delicious. You really owe it to yourself to at least try them. Hell, try everything on the menu. It's all good!!

Came here and got some delicious ramen. I'm not a huge ramen fan but I could eat here every day. Their tonkatsu ramen was delicious and not too oily and salty. It had the right amount of flavor without overdoing it. I also tried their wings and they were amazing. Very unique in flavor and made with some sort of "dry rub" to ensure that it's not too saucy (I don't care for sauce covered wings). They are probably one of the top wings I have had and will be getting this every time I come back. 

The place is very small so it is not good for big groups but they are open very late which is a plus! If you haven't tried it yet, it's a must!

This place gives great portions. I would give it 3.5 stars but I can't do half. Most of the menu had pork, and I don't eat pork. You can custom your noodles and take the protein out for something else but I was on lunch and I didn't. My friend did and she's a vegetarian. Small place but packed during lunch. Doesn't look busy at night, but their lunch had a wait like. It was clean inside and they get you in and out quick.

This place lives up to its hype.  I ordered Donkatsu ramen like most others did.  It was brought very fast.  I'm guessing they have these ready to serve due to the popularity.  We also ordered fried crab legs and chicken, which I was told very tender.  The whole thing cost $30 and change.  One of the best bang for the buck in my book.  As far as my ramen goes, it was a bit too salty in my opinion, but good, nonetheless.

We got to the restaurant at 4:50 and waited until they opened at 5:00(as others did as well). By 5:15 place was totally packed. 
Ramen was delicious. Warm with delicate noodles pork and egg. Tried the Goyza. Good. Wings were good but wanted to try the chicken bites next time. Very reasonable and nice sized portions.

I know this place is known for ramen but I had to try the Japanese curry. I gotta say it is very comparable if not, better than Coco's curry out in California. Very delicious and flavorful. The cutlet was very juicy as well. I found my Japanese curry spot in Illinois, that's for sure.

Wow!  A great ramen place (and in the burbs!)
Small selection, but everything is FANTASTIC!!
Vegetarian items available as well - the miso is the best!

I am starting off with the fact that I wish Yelp allowed half stars, they were really, really good, but just little things kept them from a 5 in my eyes.

To start, you MUST get the chicken wings for an appetizer!!!  They are delicious!  I would go back just for those!  The soups were good, with very rich and flavorful broths.  (There were three of us in our party and we each had different soups.)  The service was good, but I felt that we were ignored at points and we never got our drinks refilled, despite the fact that staff were standing and chatting with other patrons.

Call me a hater, but I always carefully look over Yelper  reviews of ramen joints.  When most people think "ramen", their limited  experience is with the packages of Top Ramen or Maruchan they buy at the supermarket. You know, those curly extruded dry noodles with a sodium-laden flavoring packet, OK?  The first time they taste "real" ramen, they think they've died and gone to heaven.  Not true for this Yelper.  I've had ramen out of automated ramen dispensing machines in the Tokyo subway, which taste better than many  of the restaurants "specializing" in ramen in and around Chicago.

I was pleasantly surprised this afternoon with my Tonkatsu Ramen at Ramen House Shinchan. The broth was milky white , subtlety flavored, and served piping hot.  In order to get that consistently, pork bones must simmered low & slow for many hours.  The noodles had what Japanese folks call "mochi-mochi" ( it loosely translates to a "chewy-texture" mouth feel which ensures that the broth sticks to the noodle.)  The garnishes included a nice slice of pork (that was well marbled, but not laden with fat),  a perfectly cooked, creamy yolk, hardboiled egg , and barely crunchy bean spouts.

While slurping at the bar, the guy behind me was served an order of "Tiwan" ramen .  It was garnished with braised ground pork in a red sauce garnished with chives.  I couldn't resist ordering a side of the meat to taste.   Slap ya mama.  It was a spicy mix of goodness.  The only good thing about winter in Chicago is a warm bowl of something when it's cold and nasty.  I'll be heading back to try their chicken-based ramen, and some of the other specials I saw flying by me.

Ramen house I have finally tried you and boy for a short period of time you have been open, you have already became a popular spot amongst us foodies at heart.
I would have given this place 5 stars had it not been the fact that without being able to see all the ingredients that go into the making of my Tonkatsu and Chonpan, that they both have MSG in it. An hour after my meal my mouth felt like the Sahara Dessert. SOO DRY, I drank 3 bottles of water within 30 min. Did not even need to use the bathroom either, I was definitely dehydrated. Also, the fact that some ramens here have cabbage...ehhh I admit not that I claim to be an expert in Japanese food, but I don't know how cabbage pairs with ramen, at least not my preference. Also I was never given water during my meal here. 

With that said. The braised pork is VERY tender and juicy, I wanted more! It only came with 1 piece of pork on my tonkatsu, no braised pork on my chonpon. I personally liked the tonkatsu better than chonpon. The chonpon looked messed, but tasted good, minus the cabbage. 

The broth, SO VERY rich, in fact so rich I took out my Tonkatsu and the next day when I took it out of the fridge the broth turned from liquid to a solid form. 

The noodle, perfect ramen noodle, no non sense instant noodle type that some Japanese places would try to trick you into. For people who knows their Ramen we all know it needs to have a good amount of bite paired with curliness and just the right amount of thickness. Not too thick not too thin. 

I would have liked a type of ramen with shrimp tampura and a whole piece of fish cake...the chonpon had fish cake in it but all sliced up, you can't really even taste it.

If you don't want to wait, come right on the dot when they open. They open at 6PM for dinner, if you come even 30 min later this place will be all seated and you will have to wait. Note that there is a gap in between lunch and dinner where they are not open. Like some reviewers have said, yes the price here is slightly higher, but honestly for the suburbs where ramen places are few and far beyond, they can justify that, as you can clearly see by people lining up the door waiting for it to open. 

Next time I am back I will have to try their fried rice and yakisoba. Definitely worth coming back. A true ramen place owned by Japanese.

I just have to laugh at what I just had here... otherwise I might shed a tear... After my first exp eating here I gave it a 5 star review and I did say it might be premature and it was...

Stopping in for a late night meal (and wanting to see if there was a wait at 9:30 on a Tuesday) I was planning on ordering a nice ramen bowl to satisfy the need. When I got there I started to look at the "Specials" menu that changes up every so often. I spotted one of my favorite things! Well favorite on a Chinese menu... Egg Foo Young, Japanese style!! I was kind of excited to see it and the waitress described it for me. Rice, sauce, and a crab cake on top. Sounds good to me, as I have had egg foo young at every Chinese restaurant I've been to and was looking forward to a better rendition for $10... What I got... a super thin, crab flavored, soft patty... made with... wait for it... CRAB STICK!!!!!! Are you serious?! Is this April 1st? At this level of establishment I didn't even think they would allow something like that in the door!! That's Jewel California roll level! Such a disappointment to say the least. You basically stir the whole thing up in the sweet sauce and eat it with the spoon they give you. The bottom line is Blah! Thank God I had a large beer and the dumplings to lift my spirits.

You might be saying removing a star is harsh but if they are going to put crap like this on the menu then it wasn't a 5 star to begin with... It's like 1/2 of a normal egg foo young patty for $10 and there is nothing in it to make it cost that much! Crab flavored fish stick is CHEAP!

End of Rant...

I'll go back but beware of the fake specials...
Awesome ramen. Not only was the tonkotsu really great, but the gyoza and chicken wing appetizers were also terrific. Worth the 30-minute wait at 6:30 on Saturday night.

4.5 stars. My coworker had recommended this place to me during a ramen discussion. I had it bookmarked ever since. Arrived here right before they opened on a weekday and there was a line outside. Ordered the tonkatsu ramen, curry ramen, a side of Taiwan meat, and gyoza. Everything was delicious. I liked that their noodles were thinner than ramen misoya's and that their menu had a good non-ramen variety. Definitely going to return to try more of their menu ;D

Outstanding ramen dishes, although some are better than others.  On the special board was Tomago Taiwan Ramen, which was outstanding.  It has mildly spicy, curry flavored Taiwanese ground meat plus egg, which makes for a creamy and delicious bowl.  Tonkatsu Ramen from menu, on its own is a little bland, but the $2 addition of Taiwanese ground meat made it perfect.  Great flavor.  One bowl is plenty of food for one lunch or dinner.

Appetizers were not as stellar.  Fried chicken was good but not great. Gyoza were disappointing -- every dumpling shell was split, and stuffing was mushy.  

Also, I tried the special Taiwanese Rice dish -- not great.  It's Taiwanese meat on white rice, and the meat works better in broth. Too curry-rich and one-note on the rice.

I couldn't be happier that Ramen House has opened right across the street from home for me. It's a small shop in a strip mall but it gets packed to the brim at all hours. My friend and I got there about Noon on a Saturday and were met with a thirty minute wait. As we dined, business didn't slow at all and I imagine the wait only grew as more & more people waited.

Service was very friendly and polite, not overly invasive, just the right attentiveness I like when dining.

I went of course expecting to order ramen but ended up ordering the Sara Udon. I meannnnnn, my name is Sarah! How could I not order this dish!? Although not all ingredients were listed, this dish has pork, squid, octopus and shrimp in it. It's a huge portion with tons of vegetables over crispy noodles with a few udon noodles thrown in for $10.75. It's not udon in the traditional sense by any means but wow that flavor was great. It's a whole lot of tasty food for a decent price. My friend has their best condition ramen which again, is not traditional ramen at all but it was oh so delicious and it's their special recipe.

My friend I dined with is Japanese and she was very happy that the Ramen House was owned and operated by Japanese, plus 90% of the clientele were Japanese. After we left, she was quite excited to take her mama to try it out. 

The food is excellent, service is perfect and it couldn't be more conveniently located for me! With so many other delicious options on the menu (donkatsu ramen, shoyo ramen, miso ramen, plus many non-ramen dishes), I see myself coming here quite often! An amazing addition to the neighborhood!

This place is well priced, fast serviced, and delicious. 

Only complaint is that the restaurant is very small, and sometimes takes a little bit to get a seat.
Decent restaurant. Very conservative with meat portions. Dishes however are pretty big.

Sitting outside waiting for the restaurant to actually open. Who closes a business at 5pm? I'm literally on my way home from work and I can't be the only person who gets dinner on  th4 way home. They would totally make more money if they were actually open at this time. Another couple just walked up to the door read the sign and left and obviously they weren't going to wait around till 6 when the store opens again when they had three little kids with them. I haven't tried the food yet but I'm not surprised people are walking away from it when you expect the restaurant to be open at 5 for dinner. They have these little rickety chairs outside the restaurant for you to sit on while you wait starving for them to feed you at 6 p.m. there's people clearly inside and the door is locked and I get that they need to stop to cook more food for dinner rush but you think they could have a shorter lunch hour and a longer dinner hour. Especially if they've been closed since 3:30 to 6 p.m. hopefully the food is worth it sitting here in my car wasting gas waiting for them to open at 6 p.m. Will update review once we actually try the food but starting now this place is a disappointment with the crazy hours.---1 star

ALRIGHT the food is freakin worth the wait! 5 stars on the food alone. I had the tonkatsu ramen and gyoza, plus a chicken ramen thing to go. The noodles were delicious and the creamy broth was amazing. I'm stuffed to the max! And the portions were really big too! I ordered extra noodles but I could have been fine without them. I also usually HATE the soy boiled eggs but theres were perfectly JUST barely hard boiled. They didnt have a smell which those kind of eggs usually have to me. I did take my order to-go, and i bet the food would be even better if you dined in. BUT the max limit of people at any point is 35 and they will only sear if your FULL party is there. No saving tables here! Eat the yummy food and go home! Def give this place a try...but be wary of the time! Still have a beef with the weird hours but I will deal with that to eat this ramen again!

Hands down the best ramen in the burbs. This place great! My wife and I have been there 3 times now and every time it seems to get better! 
I really enjoy the tonkatsu ramen...although i do get the extra cha szu pork...so worth the extra 2 bucks...as the apps go, we both liked the gyoza...which was grilled perfect. And I think our favorite is the chicken wings..it has an excellent soy ginger sauce that's brilliant. All in all well worth the 40 minute drive for us to get some REAL ramen.

I don't often sit back and think to myself, you know what sounds good for dinner? Ramen. But I did this weeknight, and it was awesome.

There were a lot of options, but having seafood in a pork broth piqued my interest enough for me to pick it over the others. Since it's also the most expensive item on the menu, it's the only thing I ate here.

This bowl of ramen is absolutely enormous. And the broth is as good as I hoped it would be - an almost-creamy, flavorful, very hot pork broth. Great depth to build a bowl of ramen on.

The egg noodles tasted, surprisingly, like eggs, and not like generic slimy starch. The meat and fish were tender, and the vegetables crunchy. A little dusting of chili spice made it complete.

The dining area is very quiet, and most of the other people dining in were Japanese, which is always a good indicator of quality. I'm ready to try a Miso bowl for the next time.

Whether you're coming for lunch or dinner, they will be open! However be alert, this place is smaller then most ramen places. You might have to wait 10~15 mins before your seated. I would say its definitely worth the wait. First timers, try their Tonkotsu ramen and Miso ramen. Service on point. 


If you didn't try Wasabi Ramen in Chicago, that's another Japanese Ramen place you should definitely check out as well!

Located in a strip mall that houses AJ's Pizza and Biscuit & Bows, This place is as good as it gets! There's so much to offer in this cozy shop in suburban Palatine IL. Walking inside, you're instantly greeted with the traditional Japanese nicety "itadakimasu" !!! Right there, you should already know... You're about to experience something truly wonderful.

If you're looking at a Ramen place review, you've probably heard about how yummy Ramen dishes are. In fact, if you aren't already on a Ramen kick, this place will get you started. The other known fact is that they are often busy at all times of the day. However, for my first visit there today, we were happily surprised to see only 2 people waiting for a seat.

They have their signature ramen dishes on a walled menu in the waiting area. I think there's like 9 of them. Then they have a slew of other delicious yummies that I'm going to check off one by one in the near future. Some of those include: Gyoza (Japanese pot stickers), Katsu Kare (pork cutlet with curry sauce), and Yakisoba ... any service member stationed in Japan or Okinawa will know what this is ;) 

After hearing reports from others about the spice factor of a certain dish they had, I didn't hesitate to order the Taiwan Ramen -- be aware that this one packs a heckuva kick, so much that even Mr Miyagi would bow down to its awesomeness. But it's not just about the spice factor. My first sip of this immensely flavorful broth transported me to another world. I was slurping and chewing, and didn't have a care about who was watching or hearing my hot mess. At one point during my heavenly trip, tears were dripping past my eyes -- either the sweat from my brow or a deep appreciation that I have a job right down the street from this place... YES!

Anyways, the Taiwan Ramen is not for the average eater that thinks black pepper is "spicy". It's for that muncher that appreciates the exotic combination of spicy hot and crazy good, such as you find in Thai food ;)  But not everything is spicy at Ramen Shinchan. In fact, I'd say there are only a few dishes in their inventory that hit this level of hot. But it was soooooo good.

Don't wait any longer. Get there. Get a menu. Start checking off items, get on a Ramen kick, and become a repeat customer. My one dish was so filling (and I'm an eater by trade) and cost about $10.82 after tax. Money well spent, IMO. -- And if you haven't lived by this well known tip before... {There are a lot of Japanese people seen eating in this Japanese restaurant which means that this is a Japanese approved dining establishment -- and this goes for almost all ethnic restaurants}.  Enjoy! ... and ... itadakimasu!!!

Ramen House Shinchan is said to be one of the top 10 ramen joints in Chicago. Eeer well including the burbs. 

With that said, I had to go check it out. 

Yeah man...bangin! I got the tonkotsu ramen with chashu and medium cooked egg. The broth was super flavorful and the noodles had the chewiness I love in fresh ramen. Chashu was nice and tender. 

My brother got the Taiwanese ramen. Nice and spicy with stir fried sprouts and pork topping. It was pretty awesome too.

Did Ramen House Shinchan live up? Yes and I'll be back often. 

Question...Every wonder why all ramen houses are tiny though?

Definitely not the best ramen in town. First of all, the noodle doesn't taste great. 

Secondly, only a slice of pork in a bowl of ramen?? That's very stingy of you. The price is definitely too expensive for a slice of pork and the rest are vegetables. Every places that serves ramen gives at least 3 slices of pork!

If you have eaten ramen in other places with generous amount of meat/pork and rich flavor of broth, you know what I'm talking about. 

This place definitely below the standard of what Japanese ramen should taste like. My instant noodle tastes better than this!
Excellent! Have I mentioned it was excellent? Had spicy ground pork ramen. A bit salty but... O M G

Had ramen for the first time today at Ramen House Sinchan, and I'm so glad I did. We were there right at 11:30 when they opened and weren't the only ones. Get there early because the tables fill!. Had the Kara-Age fried chicken for an appetizer, was the bomb! Followed by Tonkotsu Ramen, still savoring that umami goodness an hour later.

Thanks for a great first ramen experience, Result!

So good!  If Crack were soup... It would be this!

Limited seating, plan ahead or phone in/take out.

This review is for take-out only.

Given the other reviews and the line of people waiting to be seated, I thought that it would be some time before my take-out order was ready- I was somewhat shocked at how quickly it was in my hands and I was on my way.

A couple of notes about the experience:

The day that I visited, they were out of the take out menus. I chose my order from a laminated menu card, but the menu is also on their wall and on their website. It did not appear that all items on the in-store menus were listed on the website however.

I had some difficulty flagging down someone to give my take-out order to, its also a bit confusing figuring out what the waitstaff roles are, and indeed, even if a particular person is a customer or an employee.

A different person brought me my food than took my order and payment- the second person acted somewhat suspicious that I hadn't paid, and unfortunately I had told the person that took my payment that I didn't need a receipt. I felt a bit uncomfortable as I didn't want them to think that I was cheating them.

Notes about the food:

You do get a large portion but as previously mentioned, it is a bit pricey with all things considered. I ordered the Best Condition Ramen and it had a distinctly pepper finish, but overall was very tasty. The Miso Ramen that we ordered was a bit bland but it came to life after adding a bit of soy sauce.

I certainly would suggest doing take out if you can because of the other reviewers comments and my experience that getting seated can be somewhat of a challenge.

3/5

A friend and I arrived around 8pm on a frigid Chicago Saturday. I've heard very good reviews being the top 10 ramen in Chicago and needed that stick to your bones broth. It has table or bar seating you find at typical Japanese ramen joints, so be advised there will be a short wait. They have a normal menu along with a couple chalkboards highlighting some of their other specials. Neat, but I came for that tonkotsu ramen and kara-age because I was starving. 

I opted for extra cha-shyu in my bowl and came with a total of 5 pieces: makes me wonder how many pieces the normal bowl comes with. The broth was good and could taste the long simmering of the pork bones, but was missing a key element from make it amazing. As another reviewer said, I too had "soup skin" and wasn't piping hot as others have stated. For suburbs standards, I thought it was good and would come back; probably one of the better in the northwest suburbs. The noodles were slight past al dente and had good texture and the medium boiled egg (miso flavored) was spot on except being a little cold. I noticed at the end of my bowl that the broth tasted like scallion soup. Where did that pork broth go?? I would've drank the broth but couldn't handle that much scallion soup. The (small order) kara-age was very juicy from them using chicken thighs. The dip options were Japanese mayo or salt & pepper: nothing fancy and could've been a bit crispier. 

My friend had the Best Condition Ramen and asked for extra spicy. The spiciness over-powered all the flavors (I'll put the blame on his part) and reminded me of jjampong (spicy Korean noodle soup). He also ordered the miso-katsu, and although the pork was fried well, the miso sauce was too salty for my taste. I need to be corrected if I'm wrong, but I swear they put sake in their miso sauce for the katsu and thought it was a little overbearing with the combo of saltiness. Glad I had the kara-age chicken. When I got home, I didn't realize how much sodium we consumed. I understand I had ramen, but I was downing water like a bad hangover. 

All in all, I thought it was good for the suburbs. I may have come in with hopes too high. I'd come back to satisfy my tonkotsu craving, but would rather go to the city if I wanted to lick the bowl clean. As far as top 10 ramen in Chicago.... I'd have to try some other places, but I'd put them in the mid-range of top 10 best.

Ive had Ramen at quite a few places but this is the best and most authentic place outside Chicago.  I Love their gyoza too! If you go before  9 expect a wait up to 45 mins.  This place is always bumpin! It's worth the wait though.

We searched diligently for a decent ramen place because we are from out of town. Our search brought us to Ramen House Shinchan! I have never been to Japan, but this must be what it is like to eat in a real ramen house! I love the atmosphere. My only complaint is how tiny the place is- it was a bit uncomfortable. 
We came here close to closing time on a Sunday night. As soon as we entered, we were greeted enthusiastically by the staff in Japanese ('irrashaimase!'). Both the staff and a majority of the customers were all Japanese speakers, which was very awesome! We sat at a small table on the left side of the restaurant and were brought waters. The place was packed, but they took our order in a timely manner. I got the Miso Ramen and my best friend got the Best Condition Ramen. We also got gyoza! They gyoza was hot and fresh and the ramen was delicious! The Best Condition was packed with fresh veggies and had a kick to it. The Miso Ramen was savory and my favorite part about it was the egg! This place is a little bit expensive, but for two bowls of ramen, one beer, and an order of gyoza ran us around $30. Not bad!

My husband is more of the ramen fan between the two of us. He ordered the tonkotsu ramen and described it as the best ramen he'd had stateside.  It seems like that comment alone should earn Ramen House Shinchan 5 stars.

I ordered the tantan (also spelled dandan) from the specials board.  It was delicious enough that I ate it all but it was SO spicy that it was a struggle til the end. I am someone who really loves spicy food but it was too much, even for me.  They did warn me it was 'very spicy' when I ordered it, so I can't blame the restaurant.  Please note that it is a noodle dish without broth or much visible sauce, so I would even call it deceptively spicy.

The restaurant was extremely crowded and not very roomy. I would avoid coming here during peak hours if you can.  However the service was fast and courteous despite it all.  If you love ramen like my husband you should find the time and give this place a try.

Staff was welcoming and knowledgeable. We waited about 15 minutes to be seated. And people after us were seated before us mainly because we needed a high chair and inside is not big.  We went on a Sunday for lunch and there were people waiting outside before we got there.

The ramen was tasty, good broth and noodles. Great toppings and great portions.  We ordered a small fried rice for our toddler and gyoza. Our toddler's loved the food. And it is very kid friendly menu and place.

Tasty ramen. Next time will try the specials we didn't realize they had them hanging from the wall after we ordered. Clean and fast service. Will go back to try different stuff in the menu.

I love ramen. Anytime we go somewhere that offers ramen I have to try it. This place is so delicious! The portions are huge. I always have leftovers to take home so I can continue my eating pleasures of this place. Their always a line but it is worth the wait.

The Ramen Gods have answered my prayers. FINALLY. Legit ramen in the burbs. I no longer have to yearn for wasabis in the city. I got the tonkatsu ramen. Awesome broth. Awesome noodles. Perfect temp. Pork on point. 2 glorious eggs. It was a good day.

On a cold day, there is nothing better to warm you up then their Ramen. The Taiwan Ramen is spicy and a ton of flavors. I love the chunks of garlic swimming around in the broth. For veggie, the Best Condition Ramen is equally yummy. The staff is very nice, the place is fairly small. If you get there at 11:35, you will be waiting. Gyoza is good, edamame was good but very salty, calamari was just okay.

Dining in or carry out, the food is excellent and CONSISTENT. It's not fancy, it's great flavors, it's healthy portions, it's clean and I know what I am getting every time.

Definitely would like to come back and try rest of Manu.  I had tonkotsu. Soup was a bit salty but excellent otherwise.   Noodle was just perfect.  
Gyoza seems to be homemade and was really good.   Looking forward to the next.

This place such an unusual find, but I am so glad I did find it. Thank you Yelp again!
I had the seafood ramen and also some gyoza with a coworker. We loved it. It was filling, warm and so tasty. I am very excited that its authentic too. The one thing I did not esp like was the small over crowded feeling but its lunch hour so there really isnt a whole lot of time to sit and chit chat. We will go back! I want to try to fried chicken

Wow! Excellent ramen! I have a head cold and the spicy ramen was just what I needed to clear my head :) My daughter loved the miso ramen, my son also gave rave reviews to the tonkatsu ramen. They slurped their way to the bottom of the bowls! My husband said the udon noodles were superb. We will definitely be back! Fabulous find out here in the NW burbs.

This is my favorite ramen place in the Chicagoland area. I live in Chicago, but I make special trips just to go to this place. I highly recommend the Taiwan Ramen as it's spicy and has lots of garlic, but has other interesting flavors as well. The gyoza is steamed just right too.

Usually, when I'm with my Chicago friends, I have never felt hungry. This Saturday, I was starving for some reasons between way too much activities that did not involve me opening my mouth and swallowing delicious chewable items. 

Further, it took awhile to decide where to go for lunch. Though we were all hangry, no one could suggest of where to eat. Thank goodness that all of a sudden one of us yelled Eureka! Not in the tub, but in the backyard and really...what our Archimedes was saying was..Ramen. 

Before we knew it, we were in front of Ramen House Sinchan. I have never tried it before and frankly skeptical with suburban ramen houses. Ramen is tricky you know. It's hard to find a good bowl.
